IN THE BLANK SPACE IN THE MIDDLE OF THE BOARD
AT THE TOP OF THE STAIRS
AT THE EDGE OF THE HOLE
ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE ROTARY
DAMN YOU ALAN, GET BACK HERE
DROP THE GUN AND GET YOUR HANDS IN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hellish nor'easter in a New England forest. A storm of terrible power and violence. Rain blowing horizontally, tree branches clacking, wind howling. A chilled-to-the-bone night, a gravedigger's night. Anyone whe is sane is at home, by a fire. But.... A horsedrawn WAGON races down the muddy road. Two TEENAGE BOYS in 19th century clothing drive the wagon, lashed by wind and rain. The ELDER BOY WHIPS the reins. The YOUNGER BOY looks fearfully behind him into the wagon bed. LIGHTNING CRACKS, illuminating -- A TARPAULIN-COVERED MOUND in the wagon bed, jostling about. LIGHTNING cracks again. cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wagon stands near the side of the road. The horses whinny nervously, spooked by the lightning. We hear SHOVELING SOUNDS as we SUPER: New Hampshire, 1849 MOVING CLOSER, we see dirt flying out of a hole, then two SHOVELS. The boys climb out-and move with grim determination to the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Are we doing the right thing, Caleb? Maybe we should tell father.

dialogues.speaker: CALEB
dialogues.text: He'd never believe us, Benjamin. Caleb rips away the tarp revealing AN IRON LOCK BOX. CALEB (cont'd) Quickly now! The boys reach for the lock box. Suddenly a chorus of ferocious HOWLS pierces the air. Benjamin withdraws his hand in terror.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Noi! Caleb, it's...it's... Caleb comforts his younger brother, his eyes searching the surrounding darkness. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin: ‘Listen to me! It's only a wolf pack. Benjamin reluctantly helps Caleb drag the box to the hole. They heave it in, then grab shovels.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: But...what if someone digs it up? CALEB (whispered) May God have mercy on his soul. Lightning CRACKS and thunder RUMBLES. We PULL BACK and PAN, bringing into frame a GRANITE POST, on which is chiseled: BRANTFORD ---> 1 MI. and this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "BRANTFORD ---> 1 MI," marker, now weather-worn and covered with moss as -~ ALAN PARRISH, 12, small, thin, intense, pedals his bike up to a New England brick’ mill renovated to house a SHOE FACTORY. Super: Brantford, New Rampshire - 1969 Alan pedals into the factory's parking lot past a sign reading: " ri Shoes - Fou erations ual Alan throws down his bike down and enters

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan blows into an outer office, PANNING PAST A ‘SECRETARY, typing, who never looks up. He moves inside an inner office. “Sam Parrish, President" is stencilled on the door. It's oak-paneled, very masculine, with a monstrous desk and a leather chair. Below we see the factory floor. Alan sits in the empty chair. Picks up his father's pipe, tapping it on his palm, gesticulating with it. 2

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Have you seen my dad?

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE SECRETARY
dialogues.text: I'm expecting him any minute. Ready for summer vacation?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I'm working here this summer.  Ny

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marjorie looks up for the first time. ALAN looks at his father's WINGTIP dress shoes next to his desk and CUT TO: INT. “PARRISH SHOES" ~ FACTORY FLOOR - DAY CLOSE on a pair of prototype hightop BASKETBALL SHOES in motion, walking down a corridor: un-dyed canvas, white rubber, no logo.

dialogues.speaker: FACTORY MANAGER RON, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: ...Sam, if this doesn't work we'll have to unload a lot of rubber.... WIDEN to other DRESS SHOES hurrying to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: FACTORY MANAGER RON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: +...and canvas at a considerable less. This is a major makeover.

dialogues.speaker: FACTORY MANAGER LARRY
dialogues.text: It's gonna increase downtime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOUBLE DOORS bang open and -- SAM PARRISH, 40's, a pipe smoker, enters, surrounded by five Factory Managers. Sam Parrish is an educated, patrician man; if he didn't own this place, he might be teaching Milton at Exeter. They move across a cavernous factory as big as a football field. Assembly lines of LEATHER WORKERS are cutting shoe pieces, assembling shoes, etc.

dialogues.speaker: SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: I know it will Larry. Parrish shoes has stayed on top by taking risks. We'll make it up in volume. We'll convert the leather cutters to canvas cutters.... IN THE OFFICE ABOVE - ALAN hears his father's voice below. He looks down at -- ALAN'S POV - Sam Parrish and factory Managers walking across the floor. SAM PARRISH (cont'd) ...we'll put the rubber molds in the west wing. And no layoffs, Larry. We'll retrain everybody. ALAN very carefully replaces the pipe in it's holder and exits the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan comes down the stairs from the office and trails after the executives. He catches up, coming alongside his father.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Dad? Sam sees Alan but keeps addressing his managers.

dialogues.speaker: SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: I've got a hunch about athletic shoes. People are more health conscious. Trust me: there's gonna be a big demand.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (more impatiently) Dad, where am I working?

dialogues.speaker: SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: Alan, just a minute. Alan stops. Sam Parrish and the others continue. Manager Larry tousles Alan's hair.

dialogues.speaker: SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: Call a meeting for Monday morning. All employees. Heck, invite the stockholders. What we'll do is make a presentation.... Alan frowns and walks off across the factory floor.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A LEATHER APRON, upon which is burned the logo "Sole Man" and PULL BACK TO -~ INT. “FACTORY FLOOR CARL BENTLEY operating a SHOE SOLE STAMPING MACHINE. Bentley is 20, black, with a huge afro (the hairstyle of the time). This is a skilled man: his deft fingers cut the leather into soles repeatedly, wasting as little leather as possible. . ALAN enters frame, appearing next to Carl. They speak over the DIN of the assembly line.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Hi Carl.

dialogues.speaker: . CARL
dialogues.text: Yo Alan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wy Alan watches Carl. He gets an idea. Alan looks o.s,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on which are hung safety goggles and heavy leather aprons identical to Carl's. PAN TO ALAN, wearing an oversized apron, adusting oversized goggles. we looks like "Fearless Fly." He walks across the floor to the machine diagonally placed on the line from Carl. Carl cannot see Alan, the line of vision being obstructed by hydraulic lines, electric cables, etc. — . Alan watches Carl a moment, then attempts to mimic Carl's actions. He turns to the control box, presses the "on" button. He begins to stamp out shoe soles. CARL looks up, alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: . CARL
dialogues.text: Alan, shut that thing off!!!}! Carl's panic makes Alan panic. Alan stabs the "off" button, but hits instead the "high speed" button. THE MACHINE goes into overdrive, stamping double time WHAM WHAM WHAM. Alan backs off as the stamper hits the same piece of leather a hundred times (no one's there to turn it) and JAMS in the stamper mold. Tne stamper vibrates, then begins to SHUDDER AND SMOKE. The factory lights dim. Bolts fly. The blade snaps. WORKERS recoil. Carl Bentley hits a switch, shutting down the assembly line. A KLAXON SOUNDS. : The OTHER FACTORY WORKERS rush up, surrounding the smoking stamper. SAM PARRISH pushes through the crowd. He looks at the stamper, then at Alan. . Alan looks ridiculous in his apron and goggles.

dialogues.speaker: SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: (to Alan) What happened here? .* Silence. Carl and Alan exchange a glance.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: It's my fault, Mr. Parrish, Alan was just trying.... Sam Parrish holds up his hand.

dialogues.speaker: SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: Alan, go home, we'll talk about this later....

dialogues.speaker: . ALAN
dialogues.text: _Dad, you said I could work at the factory.

dialogues.speaker: SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: I think we're going to have to wait a few years. A factory isn't a safe place for a kid. Alan, ashamed, turns and walks off quickly. Sam Parrish turns to Carl.

dialogues.speaker: SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: Carl, that's my son. He could have been seriously injured. I want to see you in my office in ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan grabs his bike, mounts it, and pedals down the factory driveway. We hear a strange, supremely exotic DRUMMING SOUND. Alan stops. He looks around. He walks the bike toward --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- 50 feet away, BULLDOZERS and BACKHOES are excavating a huge hole for the foundation of a new building. A sign reads: "FUTURE OFFICES OF PARRISH SHOES." Alan leans his bike against the BRANTFORD ---> 1 MI marker. The DRUMS continue. Alan walks to the edge of the hole. CONSTRUCTION WORKERS come and go, oblivious to the sound. Are they all deaf? Suddenly there's a LOUD TRUCK HORN. The workers drop their tools and head for a SNACK TRUCK which is rolling into the construction site. Alan drops his bike and walks down into the hole.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE EXCAVATION HOLE
dialogues.text: walks through a maze of concrete forms and dirt embankments, following the sound of the DRUMS. He approaches a spot where the drumming is loudest. He puts his ear to the wall of dirt.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE EDGE OF THE HOLE
dialogues.text: An ARCHITECT and a CONTRACTOR look over some blueprints.  They see Alan with his ear to the dirt wall.

dialogues.speaker: CONTRACTOR
dialogues.text: What the hell's he doin'? a ARCHITECT Leave him alone. That's Parrish's kid. Kid's gonna own this place some day. ALAN is now burrowing, squirrel-like, into the dirt wall. THE ARCHITECT AND CONTRACTOR share one of those looks, shake their heads, and walk away.

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE HOLE
dialogues.text: exposes a rusty iron handle, then the end of a RUSTY IRON LOCK BOX. Alan grabs the handle and pulls. Alan and the box fall WHUMP! to the floor of the hole. The DRUMS instantly stop. Alan looks at the lock box. It's a curious thing. Very old and mysterious. Alan sees a SHOVEL nearby. He picks it up and smashes the lock. It's rusty and falls off easily. Alan throws open the lid. ; The contents are utterly anti-climactic. The lockbox is filled with ---~- SAND. ALAN, disappointed, begins walking up out of the hole... The DRUMS begin again. Alan stops cold. He returns to the box and buries his hands in the sand. His hands hit something. He wrestles out A WOODEN BOX. It looks like a chess or backgammon board, the fold-up kind, with brass hinges and clasp. It's decorated with jungle animals, landscapes, and a great white hunter in a pith helmet. In elaborate and fanciful type is the word JUMANJI. Alan shakes the box. Things RATTLE inside. He undoes the clasp and opens it slightly. We catch a glimpse of rich color. He hears VOICES approaching. He shuts the box and hurries out of the hole.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: ROLLING BICYCLE WHEELS and we WIDEN to Alan Parrish on his Schwin 3-speed, beginning a TRAVEL MONTAGE of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Alan pedals through this prosperous New England

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: militown. Brick and clapboard buildings: a florist, law office, bakery, Clothing store, music store, etc. -- He cuts through the small park in the middle of the square, past A HUGE BRONZE STATUE of a Civil War General ANGUS PARRISH astride a horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- He passes the BRANTFORD COMMUNITY CENTER, a pretty white clapboarded building. It's being painted by VOLUNTEERS. They wave at Alan as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A. large, grand, georgian revival mansion. Alan rolls up the driveway. He drops his bike and runs up the steps into the house, carrying the wooden box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Parrish's immense, high-ceilinged living room. Alan enters. He sits on the chair and opens the wooden box. He sees what looks like a boardgame... . MRS. PARRISH (0.s.) Alan? You home from work already? Alan closes the gameboard; stashes it under the couch. cuT To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An endless mahogany table. ALAN is alone, sullenly toying with his dinner, looking very smail.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE IN THE FOYER
dialogues.text: Sam Parrish, in a knife-edged tux, practices a keynote speech in the mirror, reading from several 3X5 cards.

dialogues.speaker: SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: +-.This year's recipient of the Parrish Scholarship Fund established in 1871 by Schuyler Parrish.... 7 CAROL PARRISH, Alan's mom, 40, very pretty in an elegant evening gown, comes up behind Sam, sharing the mirror with him, adjusting a diamond earring She hands Sam a CORSAGE. He pins it to her gown.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL PARRISH
dialogues.text: We should tell him before we leave. They exchange a glance and enter the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and Carol enter. Alan looks up.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I still don't see why I can't go.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL PARRISH
dialogues.text: It's all grown-ups, honey, mostly. business people. You'd be the only kid there.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I don't mind. Sam and Carol exchange a glance.

dialogues.speaker: SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: In fact, Alan, your mother and I think you should be with kids your own age this summer.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I don't get along with kids my own age.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL PARRISH
dialogues.text: You 1 get along with Saran.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Sarah's different. (pause) This isn't about Little League again?

dialogues.speaker: SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: No, it's about this. Sam tosses a folder on the table. Alan looks at it. INSERT - A BROCHURE OF "CAMP HIAWATHA" - several photographs depict canoeing, archery, swimming.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You're gonna send me away?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL PARRISH
dialogues.text: You'll get out into nature. » They've got canoeing and swimming...

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I'll probably drown....

dialogues.speaker: . SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: And hiking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get poison ivy...

dialogues.speaker: O CAROL PARRISH
dialogues.text: Arts and crafts...

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Give me a break....

dialogues.speaker: CARCL PARRISH
dialogues.text: It sounds great.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Then you go. I'm staying. Sam turns to Carol.

dialogues.speaker: SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: Get your coat. (Carol exits; Sam turns to Alan) You're going.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You can't make me. A pause. Father and son glare at each other. cm) SAM PARRISH CO I can't? : (a tense pause) You know something Alan? The more you want to be treated like an adult, the more you act like a child. They exchange a cold stare. Sam Parrish turns and....

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Drop dead. Sam Parrish stops in his tracks. Turns back.

dialogues.speaker: SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: What did you say to me?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Drop dead. os

dialogues.speaker: SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: We're driving you up to camp on Sunday morning. AG SAM exits into the foyer. We hear Sam's and Carol’s footsteps in the foyer, the door opening, the door SLAMMING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan sits frowning at the brochure. He picks it up and tears it into’ a thousand pieces, The DRUMS begin again. Alan freezes. He looks around. Rises. Exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan peers around the corner into the living roon. He waiks to the couch. Kneels. Pulls the game out. Leoks at it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, PARRISH HOME
dialogues.text: The Parrish's car pulls out of the driveway as - A HONDA 90 c.c, MOTORBIKE pulls up to the front curb, its 2-stroke engine WHINING like a chainsaw.° Up front is BILLY JESSUP, 15. Behind Billy sits SARAH WHITTLE, a pretty and somewhat glamorous 13 year-old. She dismounts, looking at the house with indecision.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY JESSUP
dialogues.text: Go on. Tell him. She takes a nervous breath and walks up to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan sits down at the coffee table. He unhooks the gameboard's brass clasps. Opens it. It's carved, handcrafted: a path of BLANK SQUARES winds past jungle animals, ending at the word JUMANJI. The board's center has a blank space. The illustrations are in a hyperbolic circus poster-style. There is a LEATHER DRAW-STRING pouch within. Alan opens the pouch and dumps the contents on the board: there are four TOKENS (carved, miniature African totems) and a pair of dice. Alan picks up the dice and one of the tokens. He examines it. The doorbell RINGS. * Alan puts the token down. and looks toward the door. As his hand withdraws, ni her, are sucke ° e (Alan does not see this) at the beginning of the jungle path. Alan rises, setting the dice on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FRONT DOOR opens, revealing.Sarah Whittle in the threshold.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Hi Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Hi. We HEAR Billy's motorcycle WHINING. Alan looks over Sarah's shoulder at -- BILLY JESSUP sitting on his motorcycle. He is attempting (and failing) to look like James Dean.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: What's Billy Jessup doing here? Sarah doesn't answer Alan. Instead she turns to Billy and yells:

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I'll meet you there! Billy, motor gunning, tears away from the house, accelerating through the gears.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You'll meet him where? Sarah steps past Alan; walks into the foyer, saying:

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Uhmm....so how's your job? We still hear BILLY'S MOTORCYCLE moving through the gears. Alan looks down the street, listening to it.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (lying) Great. I'm working on the assembly ine. Alan moves inside and shuts the door, shutting off the sound of Billy's motorcycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan follows Sarah through the foyer into the living room. Sarah stops near the coffee table (where the game is) and turns to Alan. 7.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: So - you ready for Saturday night? Dad says they're gonna have a tilt- a-whirl this year....

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Alan uhn, I'm not going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's the factory picnic. We go every year. Sarah nervously turns away. She sees the game on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH 1
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Some kind of game. I found it at the factory. {comes up behind Sarah) Why aren't you going? Sarah picks up the dice. Starts nervously shifting them hand to hand. .

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Because I'm going to a party.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay. (beat) With Billy?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Alan, I love the picnic but....

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (finishing her sentence) ..-but Billy's fifteen and he has a motorcycle. . They stare at each other. A very uncomfortable moment. Sarah just wants to get out of there....

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I've gotta go. She tosses the dice on the board. They land "4" and magn, Sarah begins walking away. . The DRUMS have begun again, LOUDLY. Sarah freezes. Stops. Turns.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You hear it too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah looks at the gameboard and -- SARAH'S TOKEN slow dvances by itself to the sixth square. The drums stop. Sarah, frightened, approaches the board, then Alan.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: How'd it do that?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Must be magnetized. Alan looks at the gameboard's folding cover: Printed there are engraved RULES. Alan reads them:

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (reads instructions) "“JU-MAN-JI, a game for the bored and restless. Welcome to the safari." (scans) The first to get to the end of the path and yell "Jumanji" wins. Meanwhile Sarah is staring wide-eyed at the board. ‘ SARAH Alan, look.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BLANK SPACE IN THE MIDDLE OF THE BOARD
dialogues.text: are appearing, like invisible ink in reverse. Alan reads them:

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: "At night they fly, you better run, these winged things are not much fun." The letters fade away. A moment passes. We HEAR a FLAPPING, FLUTTERING sound in the FIREPLACE. Sarah whirls around, spooked:

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: . (grabs the dice) . Let me try it.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Alan, don't. Just put it away. Suddenly the enormous GRANDFATHER CLOCK against the wall begins to chime GONG....GONG....GONG....  eC Disregarding Sarah, Alan tosses the dice. They land "2" and "3." ALAN'S PIECE now moves by itself, and the DRUMS begin, mixing with the CHIMING CLOCK which continues to GONG. The lettering appears. Alan whispers:

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: “In the jungle you must wait, until the dice read five or eight." (curiously) In the jungle you must wait. What's that mean? SARAH, instead of answering, begins to tremble because - ALAN is turning to smoke. He is dematerializing, vaporizing right in front of her!

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: What's happening....! (muting into a vague whine) Sarah roll! Roll the dice! Roollll the diiicccceee..... : SARAH blinks. He is gone. Alan Parrish is.gone. . Sarah scans the living room, trembling. She looks at the gameboard; ah's © INSERT - THE CENTER OF THE GAMEBOARD - there, in miniature, is a window into an exotic world: we glimpse green foliage and a river, and hear cawing birds. ALAN (v.o. distantly) Sarah! Sarah....!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Alan? ALAN! !?? Inside the living room the FLAPPING NOISE is louder; it sounds like BEATING WINGS. It grows still LOUDER. A HUNDRED BATS fly from the fireplace,» hovering, diving at Sarah. She SCREAMS. She runs into the front hall. She trips and falls to the carpet. A BAT lands on her shoulder. nd hideous) a mi er. Sarah SCREAMS. BATS divebomb at her, hitting her head and shoulders. She crawls to the front hall. Somehow opens the door. She runs from the house, stumbling blindly as --  ©

A fiurry of OILY BLACK WINGS rushes from the house. CAMERA HOLDS on the scattering BATS, then DOLLIES TO -- THE GRANDFATHER CLOCK. The CHIMING ceases and THE PENDULUM slooowly swings to a stop and we -~

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: The SAME PENDULUM, but it's burnished brass is now green with tarnish; the glass face is cracked. CAMERA DOLLIES AWAY from the clock through the living room. All the furniture is covered in sheets. Cobwebs and dust etc... CAMERA continues DOLLYING to the FRONT DOOR. We hear footsteps coming up to the house, then.... WOMAN 1 (v.0.) ...belonged to a nice older couple who passed away. It's been vacant two years, so don't mind the dust. WOMAN 2 (v.0.) It looked a lot smaller in the photos you sent me. We hear a KEY in the lock, then the doorknob turns; the door opens, revealing TWO WOMEN. MRS. THOMAS 40's (Woman 1), a realtor, well-dressed, red lipstick, jewelry, and her client NORA SHEPHERD (Woman 2), late 30's, attractive and simply dressed. Mrs. Thomas and Nora move into the foyer. They walk to the living room. Nora looks inside.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Oh my goodness. Mrs. Thomas, there's only three of us. What am I going to do with a place like this? WOMAN 2 (v.0.) This was all we had for immediate occupancy. The rent's very reasonable. And I got a great price on the furniture. Nora moves inside the living room, gazing at the architecture, the ceiling, the fireplace and mantle.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: The couple who lived here - they had no children? No one to inherit this Place?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. THOMAS
dialogues.text: (lying through teeth) No...no I guess they didn't....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora crosses to the window and pulls open the heavy drapes. The dusty air catches shafts of sunlight. The room looks enchanted. She unlocks the window and pushes it open.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: (forced enthusiasm) Judy! Peter! Come look!

dialogues.speaker: JUDY, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: In a minute, mom. Mrs. Thomas walks up to Nora.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. THOMAS
dialogues.text: Let's look at the kitchen. It's fabulous...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora's children, JUDY, 12, and PETER, 8, stand on the lawn, staring at the neighborhood and house. They grew up in Manhattan and show it. Judy is pretty, somewhat vulnerable. Peter is precocious, impatient, sarcastic. In the b.g. is a station wagon hooked up to a U-HAUL TRAILER.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: .Brantford Connecticut: a wholesome suburban community. They turn and look at the Parrish home. The mailbox is rusted; the lawn and hedges are a jungle; the driveway is cracked and pitted; slate roof shingles are dislodged; several windows are broken and/or boarded up; shutters hang crookedly; some fence is missing.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What a dump. They walk sullenly back to the house. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long corridor serving several rooms. Boxes are stacked everywhere. Judy's searching through a box. Peter's coming up the stairs with another. Nora is at a LOCKED DOOR at the end of the hall, trying several keys in its lock. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: vo

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Mom, where're the towels?

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Just a sec. i (tries another key) Hmm, Have to call a locksmith for this one. Nora walks over to Judy. Peter stops next to the locked door. He puts his eye to the keyhole and looks in at --

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH KEYHOLE
dialogues.text: We glimpse a picture frame on the wall and a trophy of some kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is in bed pulling up the covers. Nora sits on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Do you like your room? It's a lot bigger than your old one.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: How about Igor? What's he think? She glances at a STUFFED ALIGATOR at the foot of the bed: "Igor."

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (yawns) He misses New York.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: I bet you're exhausted. (pulls up the covers, tucks him in) Are you still having dreams? (Peter looks away) Peter? Are you?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: About dad?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Good ones or bad ones? About the accident? PETER . Not about the accident. But they're bad.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Tell me. (Peter looks away) C'mon honey. Peter reluctantly begins:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: There's this one where we're in Central Park. By the boat pond. And dad goes to get ice creams from the guy there. And then he walks away. And I say "Dad, where're you’ going?" And he keeps walking, and I go after 'im, and keep saying "Dad, stop, it's me, Peter." But he keeps walking like he doesn't know me or anything. And then I look around and all the people are gone and I'm all alone. Peter is almost crying now. Nora hugs hin.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Peter honey c'mon, it's all right now, it's all right. They hug each other tightly. Peter settles back into bed.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: You've got a big day tomorrow. (tucks him in) This is a fresh start. For all of us. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Okay.
Peter closes his eyes. Nora kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora sits on the bed. Judy is off screen, in the walk-in closet. JUDY (o.s.) But why Brantford?
Judy enters with several articles of clothing.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: The college up here was my only offer - I was lucky to get it. .Let's see what you got. (Judy holds up a formal dress) Too formal.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (holds up a denim smock dress) It's not like New York has no colleges.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Too casual. (Judy holds up a purple dress) Too purple.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Mom...I'm new. Everybody's going to be looking at me.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Try a pair of jeans. And don't be so nervous. The program here's supposed to be good.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Presenting Judy Shepherd, Resident Moron From New York.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Enough of that, kiddo. Judy, promise me you'll try. Promise?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (without conviction) Yeah, I promise.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: 'Night mom. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is sleeping fitfully. Just faintly, we HEAR JUNGLE DRUMS.  oP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy awakens. She props up on her elbows, listening to THE DRUMS. They seem to come from above. She looks at the ceiling. The drums FADE. She lies back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDY sits at a table with a TEACHER. The surrounding tables are the same set-up: one student sitting with one teacher.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: The...ap...ple is the on...

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: On the. Don't put pressure on yourself. Slower. Think about the logic of the sentence.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: on the..-. Judy stares nervously at A BOOK in front of her. She concentrates. Her jaw tightens; her face is crimson. She grits her teeth. She gives up and looks away. THE TEACHER watches Judy, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see JUDY AND HER TEACHER through a door window stenciled "SPECIAL EDUCATION," WIDENING TO -- Nora and the school principal, MRS. TIMMONS, 40, earnest, professional, a kind face.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL TIMMONS
dialogues.text: Entering sixth grade and she's never had special education?

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Not formally. Her dad was a writer. They used to work together every night. Judy was so relaxed with him; she could really concentrate. But now.... Nora's voice trails off. They walk down the school corridor together.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL TIMMONS
dialogues.text: I understand Mrs. Shepherd. What about your son?

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Peter hasn't dealt that well with it either. There have been some.... discipline problems. I think he's fine now. Nora smiles uneasily and --

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: WHAM! : A FIST flies into CAMERA and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER hits the deck. He gets up, wildly swinging at his opponent, a HUGE SIXTH GRADER. Peter, giving up 40 pounds, fights like an animal. He doesn't give an inch. The sixth grader belts him again. Péter struggles to his feet, still swinging. The sixth grader walks off.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hey, where ya goin'! I'm not hurt. Ya chicken? Get back here, ya fight like my grandmother...! The sixth grader shakes his head. The little kid's gotta be crazy.... cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora's at the sink, peeling potatoes for dinner. Judy and Peter sit at the kitchen table with school books, notebooks, etc. Nora hands Judy a newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Do I have to? : NORA. You have to. JuDY Front page or sports?

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: You pick. . Judy begins flipping through the paper.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I wish daddy was here.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Honey, dad wasn't doing the reading, you were.  23. Nora turns back to the sink. Peter and Judy exchange a look. © PETER . Mom? Judy and I have been thinking.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: What about? An uncomfortable pause, then Judy blurts:

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: We don't like it here.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: You've only been here a week.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: We want to move back home.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: We settled this, kids. This is home, and I don't want to hear another word about it.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (flips through paper) lla, How about the obituaries. (begins to “reada") The funeral of Alfred J. Bushwick was held today in Concord New Hampshire. In an ironic twist of fate, Mr. Bushwick, 68, a vacuum cleaner repairman, was killed when he accidentally turned on his own vacuum, sucking himself into the dustbag, where he survived for a week before succumbing to various allergic reactions....

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Judy.... Judy tosses down the paper and stalks out. curt TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is sleeping fitfully again. He wakes to the sound of DRUMS, clearer this time. He looks up at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, in pajamas, holding a flashlight, walks to the attic door. He turns the knob.

dialogues.speaker: X
dialogues.text: Oo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: nN 4 Tne door crreeeaaks open. Peter looks up the staircase. He shivers. He flips on the flashlight and begins to climb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the GABLE ATTIC WINDOWS, we see THE BEAM OF PETER'S FLASHLIGHT as Peter moves through the attic - and suddenly we hear PETER SCREAMING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDY sits bolt upright, hearing PETER'S SCREAM; she throws off the covers and dashes from the room into the hallway, almost running into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ~- NORA, who exits her bedroom. They both run up to -- PETER, slamming the attic door, his lungs heaving. He runs into his mother's arms.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Mom!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A VAN in the Parrish driveway with the trade logo: HARLEY PEST CONTROL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora and Judy sit at the kitchen table, unwrapping PORCELAIN CUPS AND SAUCERS. Peter sits next to them, flipping through a large, thick hook.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Careful, honey, these were your Great Great Grandmother's... EXTERMINATOR (0.s.) Hello? Maam? The EXTERMINATOR, 50, overweight, balding, looks in.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERMINATOR
dialogues.text: If it was up there, it's gor® now. They're little critters, but they make their presence known.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, it was big. Like that. Peter's pointing at a COLOR. PHOTOGRAPH in his- ENCYCLOPEDIA BRITANNICA. It's a HUGE BAT. The Exterminator looks at the photograph. Chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: or n> EXTERMINATOR © That's an African bat, son. See? Says so right there. Africa's a long way from Connecticut. (to Nora) -By the way - couldn't help notice all the stuff the Parrishes left behind. Must be a little creepy, living in the house where it actually happened. Everyone stares at the Exterminator.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Where what actually happened?

dialogues.speaker: EXTERMINATOR
dialogues.text: The little boy. The Alan Parrish thing. (beat) No one's told you? NORA takes the Exterminator by the arm; leads him out.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Why don't we discuss this outside. Nora hustles the Exterminator out of the kitchen. Judy and Peter exchange a look; Judy raises an eyebrow. They go to the door. Judy pushes it open a crack --

dialogues.speaker: NORA AND THE EXTERMINATOR
dialogues.text: are walking down the hall, speaking in low tones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “Nora and the Exterminator exit.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: No wonder the rent's so cheap. I could just strangle that realtor.... (to Exterminator) You mean all this time they never found him? There wasn't any evidence? .

dialogues.speaker: EXTERMINATOR
dialogues.text: Twenty five years now, not a clue. Personally, I don't think Alan Parrish was kidnapped.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: You mean...?  ol

dialogues.speaker: EXTERMINATOR
dialogues.text: Yep. (lowers his voice) I think the parents did it. In fact, I think Alan Parrish is still sin this house. There's a thousand places in this house they coulda hid the body, and no one woulda ever found...

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: (disturbed by this, cutting him off) Thank-you for coming on such short notice. Good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERMINATOR
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, ma'am. Nora goes inside and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERMINATOR
dialogues.text: Welcome to Brantford. The Exterminator walks off to his truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora enters, passing -- THE CLOSET ALCOVE OFF THE FOYER - JUDY and PETER, inside, look at each other with WIDE EYES. They've eavesdropped on the above exchange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the b.g., a school bus rolls away. Judy and Peter walk home from the bus stop. Judy stops at their mailbox and opens it, pulling out mail. Flips through it. One of the pieces is a FAT PACKAGE (the size of a book) in a manilla folder.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: This one's not ours. (looks around) . Come on. Judy walks off, Peter following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy comes up the walk. Peter waits on the sidewalk. Judy steps up to the porch.

ON THE PORCH - JUDY begins to slide the package through the mail slot in the front door. It won't go. Judy tries to shove it in. Still won't go. she frowns. Rings the DOORBELL. We hear approaching steps inside. The door opens a crack. TWO EYES peer through the door crack.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: I don't want any. The door shuts. Judy frowns. Rings the doorbell again. Again, the door opens.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: I said: I don't want any. As the door pulls shut again -- . Judy sticks the book between the door and doorframe.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Uhhm maam? It's your mail. The door opens slowly and we come face-to-face with -- A WOMAN, late 30's, with blonde hair, pale skin, and wire-rimmed glasses. She looks like she doesn't get out much. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Oh. Thank you. (takes the package) There was a mix-up?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'm Judy Shepherd. We just moved in. (PETER sidles up) This is my brother, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Welcome to Brantford. Town could use some new blood. (looks down street) Which house?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (points) Next door. The Parrish house. The Woman stares at the Parrish house. Her eyes spark. Her demeanor now is stiff, cold, distant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you. I have work to do. Run along. Judy and ‘peter are startled and somewhat scared by this abrupt change.

dialogues.speaker: . WOMAN '
dialogues.text: You heard me. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mrs...

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Miss. Miss Sarah Whittle. Good- bye. And with that SARAH WHITTLE, who last we saw running terrified from the Parrish house, now age 38, abruptly SLAMS the door. Judy and Peter walk quickly back to the street. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy and Peter sit at the kitchen table. Nora, dressed in a suit, is pacing, flustered, Her voice is raised.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: I have listened, Judy. (a tense pause; she stares at them) Today's my first day teaching in over ten years. I'm under a lot of pressure. What I need is less : complaining and more cooperation. . (voice trembles) We're living on a teacher's salary now and, like it or not, my job is here, not New York. (she picks up her purse) Don't miss the bus. If you get home before me, stick around the house, okay? 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Bye sweetie. She kisses Peter, then attempts to kiss Judy, who moves away.  23.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Bye, Judy. I said bye, Judy.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Bye. Nora looks at Judy a moment, then exits. Judy and Peter exchange a glance and -- 1 cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large space with a complicated ceiling (due to the compiicated roof line). The Shepherd's unpacked MOVING BOXES sit amongst ‘s ac ulati FAMILY JUNK: an old dress form, a guitar case, a moose head, old furniture, trunks, tennis rackets, etc. Peter enters, looking around tentatively for signs of bats. Outside we hear a school bus HONKING.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Judy! The bus is here! We hear, 0.s., stuff being moved around. Peter moves through the attic. Behind a trunk -- JUDY is going through the moving boxes. Her actions are harried, frenetic, her speech fast.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I can't talk to you right now. I'm really busy.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Where's the blue suitcase?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What do you need the blue suitcase for? Judy doesn't answer. Keeps looking. PETER . Are you going somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: As far as eighty-seven dollars will take me. PETER. I'm telling mom. We hear the bus driving away. Peter goes to the window. Looks out. PETER (cont'd) Oh great. It's gone. Now we'll have to walk. Judy finds a suitcase. Tries to open it.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Why is this locked?!! TI can't believe this!! She struggles with the suitcase, then throws it down. She sits on it. Suddenly her emotions run.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I can't stay here, Don't you get it? You don't have a clue, do you? I hate it here. I don't have any friends. I have to be in a class ‘for stupid people. Mom doesn't understand at all. She just thinks we can adjust to everything right away. Well I’can't. I'm going home. I'm going back to my friends.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'm your friend.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Oh, Peter, I know. I'm just really upset. Sometimes I feel....so...

dialogues.speaker: DUMB.
dialogues.text: Suddenly the DRUMS begin. Judy. and Peter freeze. Slowly look across the attic.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I knew it was coming from up here. ”

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You heard it too? Why didn't you say something?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: . Why didn't you? Judy and Peter walk to --  iS Ne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE FAR CORNER OF THE ATTIC - More Parrish stuff. Peter and Judy look at a PILE OF ToyS, GAMES, SPORTS EQUIPMENT (obviously the possessions of a young boy).

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Look Judy, that kid who got Kidnapped. Alan Parrish. It's all his stuff. (picks up a gamebox) Musta been before they had computer games. The JUNGLE DRUMS begin again. Peter and Judy exchange a glance. Peter throws off the other games, revealing, at the bottom of the pile, A WOODEN BOX; we've seen it before - it has engraved jungle scenes and the word JUMANJI on it. The DRUMS stop. Judy and Peter exchange a glance. Peter sets the box on a dresser drawer, unclasps it and opens it. TWO TOKENS are in the positions left by Alan Parri a Whi e. Peter opens the tie-string pouch and dumps out DICE and TWO REMAINING TOKENS. He reads the fold-out cover:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: "JUMANJI," a game for the bored and restless." Well, that's us. Suddenly SHUUMP! the tokens are sucked onto the beginning squares of the board.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Whoah, lookit that!

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Put it away, Peter. It gives me the creeps. She grabs the dice from him; tosses them on the board. Judy's dice tumble to a stop. The JUNGLE DRUMS begin again and -- v 's E Vv i to the appropriate square. LETTERS appear in THE MIDDLE OF THE BOARD. The two kids stare wide-eyed at the board.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (suspiciously) Old games couldn't do that. Must have micro-chips in it or something.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It's cool the way they made it look so ancient. (reading) "This mosquito's got the fever, “itchy, twitchy, sneezy fever." The lettering fades away. PETER (cont'd) Itchy, twitchy, sneezy...? We HEAR a BUZZING SOUND. THREE MOSQUITOS with 3-inch wingspans fly across the attic, divebombing at Peter and Judy. Peter flails at the mosquitos, tryirg to defend himself. Judy grabs a TENNIS RACQUET and swings wildly. They buzz and divebomb. . THE MOSQUITOS fly out the broken gable window. Judy and Peter look at each other, then at the board. Judy picks up the board and examines it, front and back. She sets it back down.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You try it. She hands Peter the dice. Peter rolls. Two "1's".

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Snake eyes. Again, the JUNGLE DRUMS begin. Peter's piece moves by itself two squares. Peter leans over to read:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: “This will not be an easy mission, monkeys slow the expedition." Immediately A CACOPHONY OF NOISE comes from downstairs. CRASHING and BANGING.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What is that? . Judy races off through the attic. Peter follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy and Peter race down the stairs and down the hallway. They stop outside THE KITCHEN DOOR. Inside, we HEAR CHINA BREAKING and SCREECHING NOISES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i Judy slowly pushes the door open. They peek in. Judy's and Peter's eyes bug out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dozen JUMANJI MONKEYS are tearing the place apart. (These are not normal monkeys: simian bodies and heads, but human expressions, movements, and intelligence.) ON THE COUNTER - TWO MONKEYS take Nora's prized porcelain cups from the shelves and heave them across the kitchen -- ON THE KITCHEN TABLE - THE BIGGEST MONKEY stands with a SOUP LADLE resting on his shoulder. He swings the ladle like a baseball bat, showering the floor with porcelain. AT THE SINK ~ A MONKEY plays with the sink sprayer. The sink is overflowing, dousing the broken china on the floor. AT THE REFRIGERATOR - SEVERAL MONKEYS are throwing food, spilling milk, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy and Peter, gulping, shut the door. They look at each other, spellbound, We hear more CUPS BREAKING.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It's not micro chips, is it? cuT To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JUMANJI BOARD sits on a moving trunk. Peter and Judy stare at it.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Read the instructions. Peter picks up the board; reads the instructions.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: “Welcome to the safari." (scans, paraphrases) ° You roll the dice to move your token; doubles gets another turn; uhmm, the first player to reach the end and yell Jumanji wins, and... (beat) - ...uhh-oh. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: \_/ PETER
dialogues.text: "Adventurers beware: do not begin _unless you intend to finish. The exciting consequences of the game will vanish only when a player has : reached Jumanji and called out its name."

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Consequences? PETER . I guess if you wanna get the stuff that comes out of the game... (they hear a CRASH in the living room) »+.back into the game.... They HEAR the door open and slam. Peter and Judy go to the dormer window and look down --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: exit the house jogging two abreast, like soldiers in double time. The lead monkey CHIRPS an order. They instantly fan out, dispersing in a hundred directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK TO SCENE - JUDY looks at PETER

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What should we do? Think of something.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You think of something. You're the brains in the family.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Maybe we're hallucinating.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Those monkeys are yea], Peter. So was the mosquito. (beat) Let's just do what the game says. (hands Peter the dice) It's your turn; you rolled doubles. Don't think, Peter, just roll. Peter takes the dice; he shakes them and tosses them. IN CLOSE-UP ~- PETER'S DICE skitter across the board and come to a stop: a "5" and a "3", totalling "8".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lo uo The DRUMS BEGIN. Peter's token moves forward; his rhyme appears. Peter reads:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: “His fangs are sharp, he likes your taste; your party better move post haste." (beat) Post haste? ACROSS THE ATTIC - A LION'S SILHOUETTE falls against the wall. He is. sitting on an upright piano. We get a sense of immense, almost impossible size. The LION'S TAIL falls across the piano's treble keys, creating an eery procession of notes. PETER AND JUDY freeze. They turn, locking in the direction of the piano. They walk across the attic, moving slowly past boxes, junk, etc. THE LION, still in silhoutte, comes down from the piano, his huge paws CRUNCHING THE BASS KEYS, creating loud, discordant chords. JuDY's and PETER'S eyes go wide. They begin to slowly back up. Further, then further - they turn and bolt from the room. The lion ROARS and leaps down, giving chase!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Judy scramble down the stairs. ‘In ¢.g.i. effect THE LION (only now do we see his entire form, and he is HUGE) leaps down to the lower floor, cutting off the retreat of Judy and Peter, who SCREAM. “they race back up the staircase, running right into -- N wit = a d i in_his ‘ He's long-haired and bearded, with a crazy look in his eyes. He's dressed in animal skin. ’

dialogues.speaker: ARRRGGGHHHH
dialogues.text: Judy and Peter recoil, nearly falling backward into the teeth of the lion; the Man From Jumanji grabs them and pulls them behind him. They race down the hallway.

“INT. ATTIC STAIRWAY/UPSTAIRS HALLWAY ~ CONTINUOUS The MAN FROM JUMANJI slowly backs down the hall, his knife held before him, the lion, following, SNARLING. Man and beast move down tne hali, reaching the end. The Man taunts the lion with the knife, urging him on The lion springs for the Man's jugular. The Man throws the knife into the wood flooring where it sticks SPROING! His hands now freed, he leaps vertically, grabbing a HALLWAY CHANDELIER directly above, the lion passing beneath him. The lion's momentum carries it into (Nora's) master bedroom. The Man From Jumanji. lands and kicks the door shut. The lion is trapped within Nora's room. We hear him GROWL and CLAW at the door, enraged. The Man From Jumanji looks around very slowly. He walks down the hallway. He stops by the linen closet door. He throws open the door, revealing -- JUDY AND PETER INSIDE THE CLOSET - they SCREAM! The Man From Jumanji looks at the kids curiously. Again, he looks around the hallway. He walks quickly down the hallway, to the LOCKED ROOM. Peter and Judy look at each other, then follow. The Man from Jumanji tries the doorknob, finds it locked and kicks the door in. Enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man enters the locked room. We see that it is ALAN PARRISH'S BEDROOM, preserved exactly as it was in 1969. A year book. A half-constructed model of a ship. A school picture of a Sarah Whittle at age 13. The room is dominated by a fireplace with a stone hearth and ornate oak mantle. THE MAN FROM JUMANJI paces around the room. The place seems very familiar to hin. He sees A STACK OF NEWSPAPER CLIPPINGS.. The Man From Jumanji grabs the topmost clipping. INSERT - THE HEADLINE reads:

The Man starts rifling through the clippings. Hartford, New York, and Boston newspapers show HEADLINES of the Alan Parrish incident: “Brantford Boy Still Missing," "No Clues in Brantford Disappearance." PHOTOGRAPHS show Alan Parrish and Sarah Whittle as kids. He is excited, almost hyperventilating. He blinks. He shakes his head. He raps his knuckles on his forehead. It's as if he can't believe his eyes. He suddenly runs from the room! Judy and Peter, stupified, follow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man From Jumanji runs down the stairs into the living room, Peter and Judy come down the stairs. They stand in the foyer, watching the Man From Jumanji. He CACKLES wildly. The following is sing-song, building to a rage:

dialogues.speaker: . MAN FROM JUMANJI
dialogues.text: In the jungle you must wait until the dice read five or eight; in the jungle you must wait until the dice read five or eight.... He turns and approaches Peter and Judy.

dialogues.speaker: MAN FROM JUMANJI
dialogues.text: Who are you? Judy and Peter, terrified, take two quick steps back.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I'm Judy. That's Peter.

dialogues.speaker: MAN FROM JUMANJI
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: We live here. “ALAN Where are the people who used to live here?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: We don't know. The Man From Jumanji registers this.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Who...are you? The Man eyes them a moment, then says:

dialogues.speaker: . MAN FROM JUMANJI
dialogues.text: Alan Parrish. It is ALAN PARRISH, now age 38, and nothing like the boy of 1969. He is lean, muscular and athletic, his skin tan and weathered. He has a steeliness, a sureness. Judy and Peter sharply inhale.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You mean...? The kid who...?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Where...have you been?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (a crazy look) Where have I been? (cackles again, points at the Jumanji board) I've been in the jungle! He boits past the kids and runs out the front door!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan exits the house. He walks across the lawn, looking in all directions at his old neighborhood. He approaches the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are the POV of the POLICE OFFICER looking through the front windshield as -- ‘ ALAN, dazed, looking around, wanders off the sidewalk into our path -- .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police car locks up it's brakes, SCREECHING -- ALAN whirls around. : %  oe wo The cruiser is going to run him over. At the last second he leaps straight up as -- \_/ THE CRUISER lurches to a full stop and ALAN lands saf on the hood of the car. THE POLICE OFFICER throws open the door and gets out, screaming agitatedly:

dialogues.speaker: GET DOWN OFF THERE
dialogues.text: The officer is about 45 and black. He is CARL BENTLEY, who at 20 was the shoemaker at "Parrish Shoes." Alan hops down from the hood.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Step up on the sidewalk, please. Alan is looking at Bentley's police car. To Alan, it is futuristic, and he is amazed.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: What year is it?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BENTLEY
dialogues.text: It's brand new.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: No. I mean what year is it? JUDY AND PETER run up.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It's 1995. Alan and Bentley move to the sidewalk. Bentley turns to Judy and Peter.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Do you know this man?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Yes sir. He's...our uncle.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BENTLEY
dialogues.text: You the people who just moved in? CLOSE ON ALAN as he does the arithmetic, mouthing the words: : ALAN (whispering to self) oe Nineteen sixty nine to nineteen ninety five that's....twenty six years...?  oN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a7 oO Meanwhile Bentley steps toward Judy, lowering his voice: He looks at Alan's strange appearance.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Is your uncle supposed to be out by -himself? Is he...okay upstairs? Judy and Peter notice, over Bentley's shoulder -- BY THE POLICE CAR ~ TWO JUMANJI MONKEYS climb through the window of the cruiser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jumanji Monkeys lock around. Very interesting.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He just came from Jumanji. Judy grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Jumanji?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: That's in Africa. Uncle's in the...Peace Corps. Bentley gives Judy a skeptical look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ONE MONKEY jumps onto Bentley's riot gun, locked in its dashmounted bracket. The monkey cocks the gun and pulls on the trigger. : THE RIOT GUN DISCHARGES, blowing a huge hole in the roof of the cruiser, destroying Bentley's LIGHT BAR.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SIDEWALK
dialogues.text: whirls around, gun drawn.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE POLICE CRUISER
dialogues.text: turns the ignition key; throws the cruiser into drive. THE POLICE CRUISER burns rubber down the street. There's no driver visible in the front seat, only wild monkey laughter coming from within!

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: What the....? The cruiser accelerates.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Don't you go anywhere! Bentley turns and sprints off down the street, following the monkey-commandeered cruiser. JuDY and PETER watch Bentley, their jaws dropping. ALAN turns and jogs the other way, heading toward town.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Uhhm Alan? Mr. Parrish? Alan stops. Turns.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What about the game?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: The instructions say we have to finish it.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: : (shrugs) Go ahead. Finish it. And he sprints off down the street! Judy and Peter stand there a moment, at a loss. They look at each other, then run off toward the house. A rotund MAILMAN comes down the sidewalk. He stops, sneezing loudly and repeatedly, scratching his back ina hard to reach spot. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan runs past the Brantford Community Center (the white clapboarded building we saw in 1969). It is a shambles. The paint is peeled, weeds Have overtaken lawn, etc. There is a big CLOSED sign over the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANTFORD MAIN STREET, CIRCA 1994 - is nothing like it was in 1969. [It's now a string of pawn shops, liquor stores, and cheap diners. Derelict cars. Trash in the gutters. Many shops are boarded up. . ALAN stands at the corner confused, blinking:

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: What's happened? What's happened here? He runs off, heading toward --  at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rotary and traffic island. A DRUNKEN DERELICT is asleep on the traffic island. The Civil War STATUE is painted with graffiti. An EMPTY BUDWEISER CAN is impaled on the GENERAL'S SWORD. ALAN walks up to-the statue. The brass plate on the base reads: GENERAL ANGUS PARRISH. Alan frowns. He thinks a moment, then he races off.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE ROTARY
dialogues.text: pedal around the rotary, hot on Alan's tail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy and Peter pedal up to the factory entrance. Below is the HUGE MILLHOUSE. The parking lot's empty. The PARR OE. E ONS AL sign is faded and rusty, but still legible. They pedal down the driveway to the shoe factory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan runs inside the factory. He looks around, confused, his mind racing. The once-thriving factory is a shambles. The assembly line machines are old and rusted. Birds fly in the rafters. Water drips down in puddles. Alan walks through the factory. He picks up a flattened "Parrish Shoes" shoebox. Stares at it. His brow knits. JUDY (0.s.) Alan!

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Alan! Where are you? Judy and Peter, come through the maze of assembly line machines. ‘They walk up to Alan. .

dialogues.speaker: / ALAN
dialogues.text: Where is everybody? My family owned this place. We employed over six hundred people. Made the best shoes in New England. Alan looks around, troubled, his emotions a combination  “Ob 43. of ruefuiness and loss; he remembers the last time he saw his father.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (looking around the . cavernous space. A lot of shoes. Alan sees something o.S., above the factory floor.

dialogues.speaker: HIS FATHER'S OLD OFFICE
dialogues.text: is slightly ajar. The door has a frosted pane of glass and through the frosted pane we can see -- THE SILHOUETTE OF A MAN SMOKING A PIPE - the pipe is of the exact shape Sam Parrish used to smoke.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: runs up the stairs to his father's office. Judy and Peter follow.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE TOP OF THE STAIRS
dialogues.text: pushes open the door

dialogues.speaker: . ALAN
dialogues.text: Dad? . He pushes open the door. The office is in stark contrast to what we saw in 1969. Wine bottles on floor. Trash everywhere. A BUM, about 65, hollow cheekbones, is staring out the window, smoking his pipe.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Sorry, I...thought you were someone else. - (begins to go, stops) Where's the shoe factory? The bum looks at Alan, then back out the window.

dialogues.speaker: BUM
dialogues.text: Yer standin’ in it. : v

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Did they build a new one?

dialogues.speaker: . BUM
dialogues.text: Nope. Went bankrupt.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Bankrupt? When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a a

dialogues.speaker: BUM
dialogues.text: i98i. Alan, alarmed, looks back at the factory. Judy takes a step forward.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Does the owner still live around nere?

dialogues.speaker: BUM
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Where'd he move to?

dialogues.speaker: BUM
dialogues.text: Didn't. Alan, Judy and Peter look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: TWO MARBLE GRAVESTONES, inlaid in the ground, partially obscured by leaves, which read: Samuel Alan Parrish June 18, 1921 - May 6, 1991; Carol Anne Parrish November 20, 1930 ~ August 19, 1991. PULL BACK TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan, Judy and Peter stand in silence, looking at the graves behind a waist high WROUGHT IRON FENCE. In the b.g., a steepled white church. Wind RUSTLES in the surrounding trees. Alan pushes open the gate. He kneels and brushes his mother's gravestone, clearing away the leaves with the flat of his hand. Alan brushes off his father's gravestone. He covers his face with his hands, remembering....

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (whispers) ...drop dead, dad....
Alan, Judy and Peter walk down a sidewalk next to the graveyard, the tombstones visible behind them.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Our dad...he died too.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: He fell. We were hiking in the  ce

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: vad o JUDY (cont'd) Grand Canyon and he went off the trail - where it was steeper. The ledge he was on broke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did your dad do?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Wrote advertisements.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: For soap and toothpaste. Hamburgers. Trucks. Lotsa stuff.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You miss him? Judy and Peter nod sadly. They walk along for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Did you miss your folks, Alan? When you went away?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, at first. Then.... (face hardens) «+-I guess I forgot about then. (beat) One thing I do remember.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Hamburgers. I want a hamburger with ketchup and onions. And cheese and... . (savors the word) ..-french fries. CUT To: A SIGN reading: "NO SHOES, NO SHIRT, NO SERVICE," and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. BRANTFORD MAIN STREET - DINER ¥* ALAN, barefoot and shirtless, staring at the "No shoes, no shirt" sign. JUDY and PETER stand behind hin.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I'll buy you some shoes and a shirt if you help us finish the game. Alan looks at Judy and --  v~ 7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4 Ov

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALAN, in stay-pressed slacks and a button-downed shirt, staring at -- A FIFTY FOOT LONG WALL OF SNEAKERS - Nike, Reebok, Keds, Converse, etc.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You said you wanted to fit in. This is what everybody wears now. Alan looks at PETER'S FEET: hightop sneakers. Alan picks up a pair of sneakers. He examines them, remembering his father's plans for the factory....

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Well, what do you know...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A GLASS being filled with COCA COLA, then lifted across the counter in front of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -~ ALAN, who grabs the coke in mid-air and drinks it in one sWallow; then he eats every last crumb on his plate and BELCHES loudly; his plate is spotless. Three other plates of food (another hamburger, chili, etc.) await. THE WAITRESS stares at Alan. TWO TRUCKDRIVERS seated down the counter stare at Alan. During the following, A WOMAN in a side booth SNEEZES periodically.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: When was your last meal?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (without looking up) 1969. The waitress frowns at Alan and walks off. One of the Truckdrivers grunts:

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKDRIVER 1
dialogues.text: Smart-ass. Alan rips open a MILKY WAY BAR and chomps into it. The counter is littered with CANDYBAR WRAPPERS. JUDY AND PETER, next to Alan, watch him eat.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Uhmm Alan?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: The game?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Changed my mind. Judy and Peter look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You promised.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You want me to help you play the game? I've been playing it for twenty-five years. I'm not going . Near the damn thing. The SNEEZING WOMAN from the side booth exits. Her arms twitch. They twitch again, more violently.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: {glares at Alan) What about the lion in our house.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah, and those monkeys....

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Call a zoo.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Alan, you took all my money. THE TRUCKDRIVERS, overhearing this, look at Alan. JUDY continues, irate, louder:

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I needed that money, Alan.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKDRIVER 1
dialogues.text: Hey. ‘ Alan doesn't pay him any attention. The Truckdrivers rise. They're huge, burly guys. They walk over to Alan. One on one side, one cn the other. They lean down. “TRUCKDRIVER 1 You take this kid's money?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: None o' your business.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKDRIVER 2
dialogues.text: (grabs Alan's collar) Hey, we're talkin' to y.... WHAM! Alan's fist slams into the Truckdriver 1's jaw. . 1 He grabs Truckdriver 2 by the hair and SLAMS his face down on the countertop. The Truckdrivers slump against the counter, out cold. Alan eats his candy bar like nothing happened. JUDY, PETER, and the WAITRESS, awed, look at the unconscious Truckdrivers, then at Alan. The waitress picks up the phone to call the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan exits, followed by Judy and Peter.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: If you're not going to help us, what are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Well let's see. What are my prospects? On the up side, I'm thirty-eight, in great shape, not bad looking and I own a little real estate - better tell your mother you've got a new landlord. On the down side, I'm thirty-eight, untrained, no college education, ny best friend's a tree sloth and I haven't taken a bath in twenty-five years. College? Maybe. Law school? Not out of the question. A wifg? Kids? Why not?.. What am I going to do? I'M GONNA LIVE MY LIFE. Alan walks off. We HEAR a SIREN and cars begin to pull over. AN AMBULANCE VAN comes racing down, Mabn Street. We hear TIRES SQUEALING in the opposite direction as -- A CAR veers erratically down the street. The Ambulance tries to avoid the car but it's too late. The vehicles clip each other, fishtail, and lurch to a stop in front of Alan, Judy and Peter.

PARAMEDIC 1 gets out of the ambulance and rushes to the car, He opens the door and pulls cut the driver -- MRS. THOMAS, the realtor. She's barely conscious, her face jaundiced. She is sweating profusely. She sneezes vidlently. Her limp hand shakes.

dialogues.speaker: PARAMEDIC 1
dialogues.text: We got another one, Larry! Paramedic 2 runs up with a portable stretcher.

dialogues.speaker: PARAMEDIC 2
dialogues.text: Jeez that's over fifty. (looks around) What the hell's going on...? JUDY AND PETER sharply inhale. ALAN looks at Mrs. Thomas closely. With tremendous urgency, Alan turns to the kids:

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: What came out of the game before me?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: There was the lion...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: ...and the monkeys...and...

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (hands six inches apart) +..a Mosquito about this big? PETER» Itchy twitchy, sneezy fever, right?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Listen to me: get as far away as you possibly can and stay indoors the rest of your life. He starts walking away. The kids look at each other. JUDY ’ Alan! Wait! They hustle after him, catching up. A MOTHER exits a store, pushing a baby stroller. She nearly bumps into Alan. The woman bends to her BABY BOY in the stroller. The little boy's face is flushed red. He sneezes,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a oo

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: What is it, honey? The woman nervously hurries off. THE AMBULANCE tears off down the street, siren WHOOPING. Alan looks at the ambulance. Looks at the lady with the stroller.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: They're all gonna die.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You itch for a day, twitch for a couple more, then you die. The kids look at each other. They're really scared.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Alan, the only way to make the mosquito go away is to finish the game. We have to finish it. Alan closes his eyes, takes a deep breath. Sighs, then:

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I know. (looks at Mrs. Thomas car) . Anybody here know how to drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -We hear an ENGINE, and GRINDING GEARS. Mrs. Thomas' car ROARS INTO FRAME, flattening the stop sign at the corner, the neighbor's picket fence, finally the Parrish mailbox. ALAN turns off the ignition.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Piece o' cake. Everyone climbs out. cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy and Peter sit at the coffee table in front of the. game. ALAN is at the window pulling shut the drapes, talking to himself.  uw ray o™ ALAN j Have fun, kiddos, this time I'm on the sidelines.... IUDY tosses the dice. They roll to a stop. Nothing happens. Judy's piece does not move.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Try it again. ALAN at the curtains, still talking to himself...

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I did my time in hell. Better you than me.... Judy tosses the dice again. Nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Alan, it's not working. Alan walks over to Judy and Peter. He stares at the gameboard. His expression darkens.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: No. No. NO. NO NOOOCOOCOO. It's not your turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy rolled first, then me twice "cause I got doubles. Now it's hers again.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: No. Look.

dialogues.speaker: THE GAMEBOARD IN CLOSE-UP
dialogues.text: There are FOUR TOKENS on the board, all on different squares. Alan's finger points to the different tokens.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: If these two are yours, who's are those? One of 'em's mine. BACK TO SCENE - ALAN looks from Judy to Peter. They don't understand. y

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Don't you get it? You're playing . the game [ started. In nineteen I sixty-nine. oe PETER So who's turn is it?  wu w

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: i ™ (sharp breath) 7 The person you were playing with.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: My next door neighbor, and who knows where she is now? (remembering) Sarah Whittle. Peter and Judy turn to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy and Peter watch as -~ Alan comes down the stairs. He has shaved. Poorly. His face is covered with pieces of toilet paper.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: She's not married, is she?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I don't think so.... aie Alan looks at his face in the foyer mirror. ( ~ He notices Judy and Peter watching him.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: What do you want? I've never shaved before. (begins pulling off toilet paper) Alan turns to face the kids. He looks like hell.

dialogues.speaker: . ALAN
dialogues.text: How do I look?

dialogues.speaker: PETER AND JUDY
dialogues.text: (lying) Really nice. Yeah, great. cur To: EXT. SARAH WHITTLE'S HOUSE - DAY . Alan, Peter and Judy stand in the street, looking at Sarah's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Le She's gonna be surprised to see me.  “~ rm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: u ow

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Kind of the understatement of the century. We HEAR a CRASH. Another CRASH as a book flies out the window. We hear SARAH screaming within the house. SARAH (0.s.) \ Stop it! Let go of that! Alan runs inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The foyer and living room is thoroughly trashed. We hear SCREAMING in an adjacent room, then many SCUTTLING FEET. Alan pushes open the door as -- AN ANTIQUE GLOBE comes rolling down a fan-shaped staircase. Alan steps aside. The globe rolls out the door. Alan looks at the top of the stairs at -- TWO JUMANJI MONKEYS AT THE TOP OF THE STAIRS who smile at him, chatter, and run away. Alan runs into the room where we hear Sarah SCREAMING.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: SARAH WHITTLE, wild-eyed, hair mussed, stands on a desk, “shooing a JUMANJI MONKEY with a broom. The floor is covered with books and ripped manuscripts. She looks over at Alan.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Who are you?! Sarah is not what Alan expected. She's no longer the Glamorous girl, but a dowdy 35 year-old, with wire- rimmed glasses, bunned-up hair, wearing a conservatively cut, shapeless housedress.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Don't panic. The monkeys aren't going to hurt you. SARAH . They're yours? You from the circus or something? I've already called the police. (points a finger) You're in big touble, pal.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Sarah, they're not my monkeys.  —~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oo

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (suspiciously) How do you know my name?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: -They came from the game, Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What game?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: When you were thirteen, you played a game with a kid down the street. Saran's eyes go wide. Her hands go to her face. She begins to tremble.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: The game with the bats, Sarah. At the mention of "bats," Sarah shudders.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: How do you know: about the bats...?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Because I was there. Sarah looks at Alan closely. She sharply inhales.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Alan? She faints...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan comes down the porch stairs with Sarah over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Did you hit her?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: No, I didn't hit her. Peter and Judy follow Alan down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOLLOWING Judy, entering with a glass of water; she hands it to Sarah on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ® uw or Sarah begins to drink. Mid-drink she stops, locking at who stands before her. She puts the glass down. Looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Let's sum up. You've been living in a magic boardgame for twenty-six years, now you're back, and you want me to help you finish playing the magic boardgame or a mosquito the size of a sparrow will kill a bunch of people. Did I forget anything?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN, PETER, JUDY
dialogues.text: (matter-of-factly) -- No. -- Sounds about right.

dialogues.speaker: . SARAH
dialogues.text: (rises to leave) You're all lunatics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah, look. Judy carries the gameboard over to Sarah. Sets it down. Sarah stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Get...that away from me. Why are you doing this to me? (stops; deep breaths, talks to herself) Compose yourself. You're thirty- eight, a p.h.d., you've had two decades of therapy, you are a logical, intelligent, rational person. She starts for the door. Alan heads her off. They stand face-to-face.

dialogues.speaker: . ALAN
dialogues.text: Throw the dice. Just once.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Oh this is nonsense.... .

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Prove it. Throw the dice. If nothing happens you can go home, call the police, and have me locked up. They stare at each other. Alan holds the dice for Sarah in his outstretched palm. Sarah sighs. Capitulates.  on ov She grabs the dice from Alan. She walks to the board, drops the dice, and exits.... The DRUMS begin. Sarah freezes, She sloooowly turns. Walks back to the board. HER TOKEN slides forward. Her RHYME appears. SARAH'S EYES widen.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
