dialogues.text: Go on. Read it.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: “They grow much faster than bamboo, take care or they'll come after you." BITS OF PLASTER fall on the game board. Everyone looks up at a CRACK in the ceiling. A VINE emerges.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (whispers, incredulous) Oh my god, it really did happen. Twenty-two years of sessions with Doctor Boorstein to convince me it didn't. SMALL VINES push out from behind pictures, out of drawers, from in between sofa cushions, out of electrical outlets, from molding around the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I was his most interesting case. We discussed denial. We discussed reverse Oedipal leanings. We entertained notions of psychosis and schizophrenia....

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Let's entertain a notion of getting the hell out of here. The tendrils are BLOOMING into PURPLE FLOWERS the size of sunflowers. JUDY ’ Why? They’ re beautiful. Peter and Judy reach out to touch them.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah. These're cool.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Don't! They shoot poison barbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VINE TENDRILS begin circling PETER'S FEET. ALAN (cont'd) And look out for the big yellow ones.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (looking around) What big yellow ones? JUDY sees the vine tendril around Peter's ankle and SCREAMS too late....

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: THE VINE drags PETER bodily toward a HUGE GREEN POD (four feet in diameter) which emerges from the glass doors of a huge mahogany break-front. The pod opens, revealing YELLOW PETALS and CARNIVOROUS TEETH within.

dialogues.speaker: ARGGGHH
dialogues.text: Sarah, Judy, and Alan grab Peter's legs and PULL. The vine is too powerful; it drags Peter, and the others holding him, across the carpet. ALAN looks at the FIREPLACE MANTLE - in a glass display case is GENERAL ANGUS PARRISH'S CIVIL WAR SABRE. Alan releases Peter. He dashes to the MANTLE. Picks up a clock on the mantle and heaves it through the glass. He yanks down the. sabre and races back to -- PETER, about to be dragged into the flower's "mouth." HACK!! the SABRE falls on the vine, cutting it in two. PETER leaps away. The vine recoils into the flower. Alan slides the sabre in his belt. Pulls Peter to his feet. Everyone dashes from the room and -- cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BENTLEY'S CRUISER, dented and shot tovhell, sits at the curb. BENTLEY'S on his c.b., looking at the house.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER BENTLEY
dialogues.text: I'm over at the Whittle residence, chief: There's signs of a ‘disturbance but no one's home. (beat) Will do. Ten four, over.  uo wo Bentley hangs up the receiver. He turns and looks down the street at the Parrish house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The foursome sits on the oriental rug in the middle of the room, the gameboard between them. This is a fabulous room, all mahogany and brown leather furniture. A bay window. Floor to ceiling books. SARAH stares straight ahead, breathing heavily.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: We'll finish the game right here. Whatever happens, we keep playing. We stop for nothing. If I tell you to do something, do it. (to Peter, pointedly) If I tell you not to do something...

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Hold on, hold on, wait.... (turns to Alan) Who put you in charge?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I did. You want to vote on it?

dialogues.speaker: . . SARAH
dialogues.text: Maybe we should.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Fine. Who thinks I should be in charge? Alan, Judy, and Peter raise their hands. Sarah grits her teeth.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Sarah, Alan's been there.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (pointedly) Yeah, Sarah, since nineteen sixty nine. "In the jungle you must wait, until the dice read five. or ‘eight?" Remember?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (defensively) What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Just something I've been asking

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALAN (cont'd) myself for, oh, about twenty-six years while I waited under a stinking palm tree for somebody to ROLL A DAMN FIVE OR EIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I was scared! I still am scared.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Unm people? Hello? (they look at Peter) Can we argue after we finish the game?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Fine. Alan's in charge. Saran gives Alan a conciliatory look. Alan, in a conciliatory gesture, extends his hand. Sarah shakes Alan's hand. After the shake, Alan's hand is still outstretched. .

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: The dice. Sarah frowns. Hands Alan the dice. Alan shakes the dice and rolls for the first time since 1969, and reads:

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: "There is a hunter proud and true, it's not your day, he's mad at you.” Alan rises quickly as if expecting the worst. He looks around nervously.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Oh no. Van Pelt.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Who's van Pelt? A SHOTGUN BLAST blows in the bay window of the library. Alan dives to the carpet, the shot going wide. Sarah and the kids whirl around, terrified, ‘to see --

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BACK YARD
dialogues.text: is drawing a bead on Alan with a shotgun. This is VAN PELT, an imperialist Transval Englishman from a bygone era. He is laconic, humorless; a remorseless killer. ALAN bolts across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6c. VAN PELT leans in the bay window and BLASTS again. The shots RIP into the moulding, missing Alan by inches. Van Pelt climbs into the library and moves past -- SARAH, JUDY, and PETER, who cringe in terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALAN dashes down the corridor for the front door. van Pelt emerges from the library, drawing another bead. Alan pulls the sabre from his belt and heaves it at Van Pelt, javelin style. The sabre rips through the sleeve of Van Pelt's bush jacket and SPROING!. sticks into the wall, pinning Van Pelt, throwing off his aim. Alan dashes out the front door. . Van Pelt rips the jacket from the sabre and pursues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALAN bursts from the house, sprinting across the front lawn and down the street. VAN PELT exits calmly, reloading. He FIRES again, then follows Alan down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BENTLEY, at Sarah's house, looks up, wide-eyed, as -- ALAN sprints down the street past him. VAN PELT, walking quickly, precisely, comes down the street, aiming yet again.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE. FREEZE.
dialogues.text: Van Pelt freezes, his jaw muscles twitching. OFFICER BENTLEY is behind the door of his cruiser, about 20 yards away, his pistol trained on Van Pelt.

dialogues.speaker: DROP THE GUN AND GET YOUR HANDS IN
dialogues.text: THE AIR. ’ van Pelt, instead of obeying, wheels on Bentley, BLASTING at the cruiser. Bentley hits the deck as -- BENTLEY'S CRUISER is blasted apart by round after round from Van Pelt's shotgun....the front and back windshield... the headlights...glass rains down.... VAN PELT turns on Alan. He's got a clear shot.  He squeezes the trigger. CLICK. Van Pelt's out of ammo. He curses and sprints into the woods of the surrounding property. BENTLEY slbwly emerges from behind the door, looking around. He frantically reaches inside the cruiser, grabbing his c.b. radio.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: I got an armed and dangerous perpetrator on Blair Street! A caucasian male with one helluva big gun! Ten four, over! (gets behind the wheel) Don't go anywhere. I mean nobody. Bentley ROARS off, tires SQUEALING. Alan comes back down the street. SARAH, JUDY, and PETER run up. They stare at Alan and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .The foursome reenters. They take their places around the gameboard. Alan picks up the dice and hands them to Judy. Judy begins to roll. Sarah restrains her hand.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Who was that man? (no response) Alan, if there are people in there trying to kil] you....

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (sighs) His name's Van Pelt. He hunts. Right now he happens to be hunting me. PETER ’ He hunts people?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What if he comes back?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Run like hell. Alan hands the dice to Judy.  62. Judy rolls; her piece moves; her rhyme appears on the —~ board. She stares blankly at her rhyme. ue . ALAN Go ahead, read it. JUDY'S face reddens. She looks at PETER with beseeching eyes. Peter leans over to read Judy's rhyme.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: "Don't be fooled, it isn't....”

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. (turns to Judy) It's your turn, you read it. Judy doesn't respond. Another pause.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Uhhm, Alan.... {beat) Judy can't read.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: What do you mean she can't....? ‘ (turns on Judy again) li How old are you? — JUDY (uneasy) Twelve.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You're twelve and you can't read? (beat) You're kidding, right? You're not kidding. Judy turns away, trembling with embarrassment. Her face scrunches up; she's nearly crying.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Leave her alone, Alan. Sarah puts her arm around Judy and whispers. : SARAH . i It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: She has dyslexia. It's a reading LO disability. : io ALAN How could I know? Stop crying. Stop crying, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy stops. She rubs her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: There. You're fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not fine. You hurt her feelings. What's the matter with t you?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (turns to Judy) Look, I'll read it myself, okay? (reads Judy's rhyme) "Don't be fooled, it isn't thunder; staying put would be a blunder." A slight RUMBLING is heard in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Sure sounds like thunder. Alan is wary. He frowns, listening to the RUMBLE. He walks across the library to the bookstack on the far wall. The others follow. The RUMBLING continues.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What is that? Alan ignores Peter and focuses on the bookstack. The RUMBLING grows louder; the BOOKS begin to SHAKE and VIBRATE. In an instant it dawns on Alan:

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Stampede! Alan grabs Judy and Peter and hauls them across the room, pushing Sarah in front of him just as -- e@ wa. 2 i ma, -- A HERD OF RHINOCEROSES bursts through the BOOKSTACK and charges across the library! Sarah and the kids, looking over their shoulders, SCREAM! ALAN pushes everyone into the hallway and -- INT. PARRISH HOME - HALLWAY . -- They race pell mell toward the living room. The RHINOCEROS HERD smashes through the library's french doors and comes after them! Behind the rhinos is a HERD OF ELEPHANTS! The rhinoceroses bear down on then. Their HOOF BEATS are deafening. Their SNORTING BREATH is six feet away!  c™~ The FOUR PLAYERS DIVE into the living room as the animals ROAR past them down the hallway, SMASHING the west wall of the house to bits; THEY STAMPEDE RIGHT THROUGH IT into the side lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The foursome tumbles into the living roon. Each gathers himself and looks at an awesome sight: THE ANIMALS charge past the living room. It's a living, breathing freight train: RHINOS, then ELEPHANTS, and ZEBRAS. POUNDING HOOVES and BREAKING FURNITURE. Finally it's over. The FOUR PLAYERS slowly rise; they timidly move to the living room threshold. They look down the hallway. It's a total wreck, as if it's been bombed. The floor is covered in rubble. Part of an exterior wall is missing. Dust hangs in the air. A FLOCK OF PELICANS flap past them and out the front door. The LAST PELICAN is enormous, with a six foot wingspan. It flies into the parlor and lands -- -- amidst the rubble next to THE GAMEBOARD. The big bird looks at the board. Suddenly it snatches it up in its bill. .

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Hey! No you don't. Its too late. THE PELICAN, gameboard clenched in bill, lifts off from the coffee table, taking flight. Alan, Sarah, Peter and Judy chase it across the room. .

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! Damn it, come back! The pelican flies out the shattered living room window and lifts above the trees, flying toward town. The foursome stands at the window, grim, in silence. Suddenly a TELEPHONE RINGS, the sound muffled. . Judy and Peter look at each other, gulping. Judy follows the RINGING to its source. She pulls the TELEPHONE out from under a bunch of rubble. Answers:

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Hello. ° NORA (v.0.) Hi, it's mom. How was school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: po, vO

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Uhmm, great, mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora's behind her desk in her new office. Cartons of books, some opened, some not, are all over the place. In the b.g., during this, are several ACADEMICS (Nora's new colleagues).

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Listen, honey, I've invited some of my department over for dinner tonight. Make sure the place is picked up, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy looks around the destroyed house, grimacing:

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Sure, mom. See ya in a little bit. Judy hangs up and walks back to the others. They're still staring out the window.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (still grimacing) My mother's coming home. Peter looks at Judy and gulps.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What are we going to do? That thing could've flown to China.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Pelicans like water.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Where's the nearest body of water? SARAH/ALAN (unison) The Brantford River.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WINDOW DISPLAY of pawn shop JUNK including firearms: rifles, shotguns, handguns, as we WIDEN TO -- The stern hunter VAN PELT, on the sidewalk, staring at the display. He walks inside the store.  66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two oily SALESMEN smoking cigars and a filterless cigarette sit behind the counter. Van Pelt.ehters, wearing jodhpurs, a cape, and a pith helmet. The Salesmen give him a queer look.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMEN 1
dialogues.text: (grunts) Morning. Van Pelt slides the action of his gun, EJECTING a spent cartridge which flies into the hand of Salesman 1, who examines it.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: What the hell is this? (tosses it to the other salesman) Lenny, we carry these?

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN 2
dialogues.text: Hell no. Sterling and Johnson 6 gauge. That company went belly up in 1903.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN 1
dialogues.text: You want real ammo, you're gonna have to get a real gun, buck-o. You a hunter? (Van Pelt nods) What do you hunt?

dialogues.speaker: VAN PELT
dialogues.text: Animals.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN 1
dialogues.text: You look like you got an eye for quality. Lemme interest you in this. . The Salesman reaches under the counter, pulls out a HUGE SNIPER RIFLE with a telescopic sight.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Tap of the line. How do you love it? . Van Pelt nods. He withdraws a MONEY PURSE from his cape. Pulls out BILLS OF CURRENCY and hands them over. The currency is AFRICAN TRANSVAL, circa 1900.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: You some kind o' joker? Van Pelt doesn't react; he withdraws gold coins and  aN
tosses them on the counter. The Salesman's eyes light up. He picks one up. Bites it.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Now yer talkin’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VAN PELT exits the pawnshop ‘vith the high-powered rifle. He smiles, revealing many gold teeth. DOWN THE STREET - A POLICE CRUISER pulls onto Main St. Van Pelt stows the rifle under his cape and ducks into THE ALLEY next to the pawn shop as -- OFFICER BENTLEY drives by, scanning the street in front of him, talking on his c.b. radio. cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA MOVES headlong through REEDS ‘and BULLRUSHES. TWO HANDS gently part the reeds before us, revealing -- THE PELICAN standing on a BIG FLAT ROCK in the river close to the riverbank. This is an enormous bird. The JUMANJI GAMEBOARD sits at his feet, precariously hanging over the rock's edge. The river swirls below! ALAN, on his hands and knees in the bullrushes, watches the pelican. Alan creeps across the bank onto the big rock. He tip-toes across the rock to the pelican. The pelican suddenly turns. Glares at Alan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A low bridge, about 100 feet long, connecting the Parrish neighborhood to the town center. Alan and the pelican are below, upstream, 50 yards from the bridge. PETER, JUDY and SARAH stand on the bridge watching Alan, whispering:

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: How in the world is he going to...? : ‘

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Watch. He can do anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan, on hands and knees, creeps forward. His hand extends, sloooowly, toward the GAMEBOARD.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Hey there, bud. You got something of mine. I want it back. Just a foot away now. Now six inches. Alan lunges for the board. The pelican SNAPS at Alan's hand, nipping it. Alan falls on his butt, grabbing his sore hand. The pelican, a rather territorial fellow, glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You son-of~a....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah turns to Peter with a glum expression:

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You were saying? She looks down at the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan is perched on the edge of the rock opposite the pelican, looking into THE WATER.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Okay, let's try the barter system. Alan pauses a second, then, like a Metabale Tribesman, thrusts his hands into the water. His hands emerge holding....A BIG FLAPPING FISH! ON THE BRIDGE ~ SARAH, PETER and JUDY watch this feat with utter awe. Even SARAH, in CLOSE-UP is amazed, and she whispers to herself:

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: My god...

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ROCK
dialogues.text: turns to the pelican with the fish, dangling it in front of him. The pelican opens its mouth.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN 8
dialogues.text: Ya like that do you? He tosses the fish across the rock. The pelican LUNGES at it, swallowing it whole as -~ ALAN grabs for the gameboard. But it falls in the river! The current takes it quickly downstream, moving toward the iron bridge!  Oo 69. ALAN sprints across the face of the rock and leaps, in acrobatic succession, to FOUR OTHER ROCKS jutting up in the river, with each rock moving closer to the bridge. Alan leaps from the last rock to the BRIDGE TRESTLE, clinging tO the trestle with his hands. He pulls his feet up, lodging them in the trestle, then hangs upside down over the rushing current as -- THE GAMEBOARD comes WHOOSHING by. Alan snags the gameboard out of the river and pulls himself up to the trestle. He climbs up to the bridge. JUDY and PETER run over to Alan, CHEERING. They pat hin on the back. Alan hands Peter the gameboard. Sarah stands off at a distance.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: That was great!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (to Sarah) I told you he could do it! Alan looks at Sarah. She smiles slightly.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: That was pretty impressive Alan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora is driving along a treelined street toward Brantford, listening to the radio. RADIO NEWSCASTER (v.0.) ...now an update on that news from Brantford Connecticut. Nora looks at the radio; she turns up the volume. RADIO NEWSCASTER (v.a.) According to sources at Brantford Community Hospital, fifty-seven residents have been hospitalized with symptoms ranging from rausea and rashes to violent seizures. WKOR's Phyliss Matthews is at the hospital. Phyliss? REPORTER PHYLISS MATTHEWS (v.a.) Richard, at eleven-o'clock this morning the hospital began receiving calls from Brantford residents with these symptoms.....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oo 70. Nora stares at the radio with a worried expression. cUuT To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van Pelt looks down at the bridge. Raises his new rifle. Looks through the scope.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH TELESCOPIC SIGHT
dialogues.text: We see Alan, Sarah and the kids on the bridge. THE CROSS HAIRS are locked on Alan's head. Before Van Pelt can squeeze off a shot, Alan moves behind a steel girder. The CROSS HAIRS fall upon Peter with the JUMANJI GAMEBOARD. We can read "Jumanji" on the board.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: lowers the rifle. Thinks. His eyes glint. He turns to walk away. The SPIKE on his pith helmet hits a tree branch. The helmet falls to the ground. Van Pelt snatches it up. Puts it back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter has the game open. He looks at his token. With his finger, he counts the number of spaces he'll need to reach the end. He thinks....hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The foursome is walking from the bridge. Alan and Sarah in the lead, the kids following behind.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I've never told anyone this, Alan. Well, except my shrink - all these years I knew you were alive. Somehow I knew I'd see you again.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I never thought I'd see you - or anybody - again. (beat) Why are you still in Brantford? What'd you use to call it? Blandford? : (Sarah smiles, remembering) Sarah, what's happened to you? I thought you were on your way to New York to become an actress? .

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Oh I don't know....the night you went away everything changed. After  a SARAH (cont'd) the police and newspapers got through with me, you just can't imagine.... .

dialogues.speaker: . ALAN
dialogues.text: You never got married?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Nope. People just stayed away. "There goes Sarah Whittle, the kid who saw Alan Parrish murdered...." (beat) I couldn't tell anyone what happend. Everyone thought I was crazy. After a while I thought I was crazy. I was so alone.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: What de you do now?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I'm a writer.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (smiles) Really? Novels?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Encyclopedia articles.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Oh. A pause. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I‘m sorry Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not your fault.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I found the damn thing. (beat) Did you ever think about me? » SARAH ‘ Every day for twenty-six years. Did you think of me? . Before Alan can answer.... JUDY (0.s.) Peter, don't!  72. Alan and Sarah look over at -- oy DOWN THE STREET - PETER AND JUDY are kneeling over the ~ game. Alan and Sarah run over to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: He tried to end the game.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (to Peter) You did what? Peter nervously stares at his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: He didn't get a high enough roll so he tried to change the dice. EVERYONE looks at THE BOARD - The following rhyme appears: ,

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: A law of Jumanji having been broken; You will slip back even more than your token. PETER'S TOKEN moves backward to the beginning space. BACK TO SCENE ~ ALAN glares at Peter.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (biting) That was really smart.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I...I'm sorry. Peter walks away. Alan grabs him by the shoulder and spins him around.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You know how dangerous this thing is.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I said I'm sorry!

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Sorry's not good enough. If you were twenty years older I'd beat the living.... Cc. SARAH . He's not twenty years older. Leave him alone. He's just a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: fo

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Well I'm sorry, Sarah, I wouldn't know what that's like. I didn't have time to be a kid. Alan stalks off. Then: JUDY (0o.s.) Your hand, Peter. Look at yeur hand. Alan whirls around. Everyone is looking at Peter Peter holds up his hand. He holds up the other. Both are growing dark fur!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (trembling) What's happening to me?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (whispering) It's the curse. We HEAR an ENGINE GUNNING. Everyone whirls around -- OFFICER BENTLEY'S POLICE CRUISER is approaching!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bentley at the wheel passes Alan and the others. He doubletakes. He slams on the brakes; throws the cruiser in reverse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cruiser, tires SQUEALING, backs up at 20 m.p.h., moving back toward the foursome. ALAN turns to Peter. ALAN . Hide it. Peter quickly grabs the gameboard and folds it up. THE POLICE CRUISER lurches to a Stop. BENTLEY gets out, radio in hand.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: I got him, chief. Right in front of me, Bring him in? Right, ten four, over and out. He hangs up the receiver. Warily approaches the foursome.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: You know these people, Miss Whittle? SARAH . It's all right, Carl. They're my heighbors.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: (points at Alan) What about him?

dialogues.speaker: . SARAH
dialogues.text: Uhhmm...he's...

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Don't lie to me. I know something's going on. Bentley stares at Sarah. She nervously stares back. Bentley approaches Alan.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: A whole lotta weirdness started about the time I saw you this morning. (sternly) Who are you? Don't give me any of this "Peace Corps" b.s. Show me some I.D. A nervous pause. Alan doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: You're gonna have to come down to the station for some questioning. Another nervous pause. And Alan sprints off! A GUNSHOT splits the air, then: BENTLEY (0.s.)

dialogues.speaker: FREEZE
dialogues.text: BENTLEY, gun drawn, approaches Alan.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Turn around. Hands on the car, feet spread. Bentley shoves Alan against his cruiser. Frisks him. Cuffs him. Bentley shoves Alan into the cruiser, saying to Sarah, Judy and Peter:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ur BENTLEY . Don't you go anywhere - I'm gonna want some answers from you. As Alan disappears into the cruiser, he worriedly looks at SARAH, JUDY and PETER. The cruiser roars off, heading back to town.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What do we do now? Sarah watches the cruiser drive off. Thinks. cuT To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stone wall has been smashed; it has fallen in the road. A car sits in the middle of the road, its top caved in. It looks like a freight train plowed through the area. There's a commotion, lot's of activity; flashing lights and parked vehicles; men hurrying around. A police cruiser and firetruck block the road. Nora Shepherd's station wagon pulls up. Nora rolls down her window and shouts at -- Brantford Police Chief GARNETT walking by with TWO FIREMEN. Nora calls to him:

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Officer! (Garnett approaches) What's going on? :

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GARNETT
dialogues.text: Sorry maam, this road's closed. You'll have to find some other way through. Chief Garnett walks off with the firemen. Nora, perturbed, backs her car around and heads the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bentley drives. Alan, handcuffed next to Bentley, looks out the window at the passing buildings.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: The town's sure changed.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: How would you know?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I grew up here.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: The hell you did.. I've lived here all my life - know everybody - I've never seen your mug before.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Yes you have, Carl.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: (unnerved) How do you know my name?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You worked at Parrish Shoes.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Right....

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: On the stamping line.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, 'till old man Parrish fired me. :

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: What? He did?

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: His kid wrecked a machine. Like an idiot I took the blame. He fired me on the spot. : Alan looks out the window, then at Bentley.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Well, if it's any consolation, I apologize.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: For getting you fired.... (beat) +..Sole Man. Bentley looks in the rear view mirror, studying Alan's face. His eyes widen; he sharply inhales. It hits him like a hammer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bentley's cruiser SCREECHES to a stop, fishtailing.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A TELESCOPIC SIGHT ~ through which we see --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy, Sarah, and Peter walking along. The crosshairs jump back and forth as Van Pelt searches for Alan. Again the crosshairs fall on -- THE JUMANJI GAMEBOARD in Judy's hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bell tower six stories above the town square. Van Pelt lowers the gun. Thinks. As he turns away, the SPIKE on his pith helmet hits the lip of the CHURCH BELL. The helmet falls to the floor. Annoyed, Van Pelt picks up the helmet.

dialogues.speaker: VAN PELT
dialogues.text: Blasted thing. He puts the helmet back on and cinches the chin strap tight UW. i = «+ The helmet secure, he continues into the stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The consequences of the Jumanji game are in full bloon. The place is a disaster. Sarah, Judy and Peter walk down the street, nervously looking around. It is chaos. -- Stores have been pillaged by monkeys and/or people. -~ CARS are parked helter skelter, some in the middle of the street, some on the sidewalk. -- an AMBULANCE races past. -~ A MAN lurches down the sidewalk, face flushed, sweating, clearly diseased. -~ We HEAR MONKEY CHATTERING in the windows of a store above, then merchandise comes flying out. A MOTORCYCLE ZOOMS past. It's driven by FIVE MONKEYS. The motorcycle is followed by -- A deep RUMBLE. We've heard it before. Sarah and the kids freeze. Look down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their eyes bug out in terror and they dive inside a storefront as -- THE ELEPHANT, ZEBRA AND RHINOCEROUS HERD stampedes peil mell down the center of the street. Elephants fling cars aside’like toys. ; Finally it passes. Sarah and the kids emerge from the storefront. They continue down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora Shepherd's station wagon approaches at high speed an old New England covered bridge. INT. NORA'S STATION WAGON ; Nora drives inside the bridge. Suddenly -- THE SILHOUETTE OF A HUGE BULL ELEPHANT fills the bridge in front of her. NORA stomps on the brakes and whips the wheel. The car fishtails and SMASHES into the side of the bridge, splintering the wooden sides and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- exploding through the wall of the bridge and diving into the Brantford River. The car slowly submerges. Seconds pass. Nora bobs to the surface. She swims to shore. Gets out on the bank. Looks up at the bridge. We hear the elephant trumpeting inside the bridge. Nora, dazed and confused, scrambles up the bank and jogs down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah is punching in her code at. an AN AUTOMATED TELLER MACHINE. Judy and Peter stand behind her.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Five hundred dollars should bail him out. Judy SCREAMS. SARAH whirls around, and standing before them is --  rc The hunter Van Pelt! Peter quickly tries to hide the gameboard behind his back; Van Pelt yanks it from him, Sarah and -the kids watch nervously as -- VAN PELT looks at the gameboard. He finds it very interesting and we see why.... INSERT - THE GAMEBOARD - the great white hunter depicted on the exterior cover of the board is Van Pelt! VAN PELT looks up, eyes glinting. Then he whirls and stalks off, the gameboard in one hand, his rifle in the other!

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What do we do now? In agony, Sarah and the kids watch Van Pelt walk off --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan (nis hands now uncuffed) and Bentley lean against Bentley's cruiser. Bentley's laughing, shaking his head. He can't get over it....

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: I don't believe this, I do not believe this. So if you didn't get kidnapped, what did happen?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I guess you could say I got lost.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Shoot, Alan, the town hasn't been the same since you left.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Couldn't have been that big a deal.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? Look around nan, the place is falling apart. *

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I caused that?

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Maybe not directly. But the day you disappeared your dad, well, he just seemed to lose interest. Stopped coming. to work. Started drinking.

BENTLEY (cont'd) Your mother too. The factory went down the tubes, I don't know if you've seen it yet... (Alan neds) You were everything to them, man. Alan's brow knits. His expression turns sad. This has taken him by surprise. A pause. Bentley's.CAR RADIO BEEPS. Bentley turns.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: We got an epidemic, wild animals running around, and now Alan Parrish comes back to town, What a day. 'Scuse me. Bentley turns and leans inside his car. Alan looks at BENTLEY'S HANDCUFFS clipped to his belt.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY , \
dialogues.text: Ten-four, this is Bentley. Chief, you're not gonna believe this.... Suddenly ALAN'S HAND thrusts inside the window and YANKS the keys from the ignition.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Hey...!! Bentley, startled, turns and -- CLICK a handcuff locks on Bentley's wrist and CLICK the other cuff locks on the FRAME OF THE CAR DOOR. :

dialogues.speaker: WHAT THE HELL YOU DOIN
dialogues.text: ALAN stands there, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Carl, I can't explain now but this is for your own good. ALAN tosses Bentley's keys across the road, turns, and sprints down the street, leaving -- BENTLEY locked to his car door, SCREAMING --

dialogues.speaker: DAMN YOU ALAN, GET BACK HERE
dialogues.text: Bentley reaches inside, grabbing his c.b. transmittor. Clicks it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Tnis is car twelve, Bentley, over! (beat) Come in, over! We HEAR JUMANJI MONKEYS CHATTERING on the other end. Bentley stares at the c.b. transmittor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is trashed. Van Pelt strides in and walks to the counter. With a violent sweep of his hand, he clears the counter. Sets the gameboard down. Looks at it. Picks up a screwdriver. Pokes at it. He unclasps the box. Opens it. Stares at it. Frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah and the kids, crouched behind the window display (the window is smashed), peer inside the hardware store, whispering to each other.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Dees he know what it is?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I don't think so. We've got to distract him...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah! Create a diversion! Like in the movies! Next to the hardware store is a LADY'S BOUTIQUE. Judy looks at Sarah, then the boutique.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Sarah, there's only one thing to do. Judy beckons Sarah toward the boutique.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: van Pelt. is now looking at THE INSTRUCTIONS ON THE GAMEBOARD. He reads them aloud.

dialogues.speaker: VAN PELT
dialogues.text: (reading to himself) ",,.do not begin unless you intend to finish. The exciting consequences of the game will vanish....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VAN PELT (cont'd) (looks up, concerned) «only when a-player has reached Jumanji and called out its name...." {looks up again) - Bloody hell. Van Pelt looks at his likeness on the cover. He looks over at -~ AGAINST THE WALL is a shelf stacked with cans of KEROSENE and CHARCOAL LIGHTER. Van Pelt thinks. He knows now what to do. He grins evilly. Walks over to the kerosene. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE- UP of SARAH'S EYE as an EYELINER traces a line under it and WIDEN TO -- JuDY, seated before Sarah, applying the make-up. Sarah has transformed. Her eyeglasses are history. She wears red lipstick. Her hair falls about her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Now for the final touch. She unbuttons the top two buttons of her dress.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What do you think? Judy and Peter study Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Ya know, Sarah, you've got a nice figure.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I do?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (nods) Three more. Sarah uncertainly unbuttons three more buttons, exposing her surprisingly stupendous cleavage! Then Judy bends down and rips off a two foot swath of Sarah's dress, making it into a miniskirt! Sarah no longer looks like Marian the Librarian. She is exotically, wonderfully, beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah. That's better.  la

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boardgame sits on the floor. Van Pelt is dousing it with kerosene. He grabs an EMERGENCY CAR FLARE, pulis it apart, yanking off the fiint. Just as he's about to ignite the car flare.... SARAH (0.s.) Oh Mr. Van Pelt.... Van Pelt, startled, looks over at -- SARAH WHITTLE in the threshold, leaning seductively against the door, newly glamorized. VAN PELT raises an eyebrow. Sarah approaches Van Pelt, putting extra sway into her hips as she walks. She purrs.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Tell me - are all men from Jumanji as handsome as you?

dialogues.speaker: VAN PELT
dialogues.text: Go away woman. You're not getting it back.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Getting what back? . (looks at the board) Oh, that? I don't want that, I want you. (sidles up next to him) What's the matter, handsome, don't you like girls?

dialogues.speaker: VAN PELT
dialogues.text: I've had my share.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I bet you have. You don't know how long I've been waiting for a man like you. With all the wimps around here.... . She looks over Van Pelt's shoulder at THE GAMEBOARD on the floor and JUDY outside the shop, waiting for a chance to snatch the board. Sarah feels Van Pelt's arms.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Oh my my my feel that...  i) o She turns Van Pelt, so his back faces the board. JUDY creeps inside the store, going for it. Van Pelt turns around. Judy jumps back outside. Sarah runs*her hand across Van Pelt's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I'm Sarah. What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: VAN PELT
dialogues.text: Magnus.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Oooh. Magnus. I like that. She turns Van Pelt again. Judy creeps.in, then jumps back out as Van Pelt turns.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Magnus, why don't we go back there, where we can be more.... (winks) ...comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: VAN PELT
dialogues.text: I'm comfortable right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Judy are crouched outside the store. They hear FOOTSTEPS and turn to see --- ~~ ALAN running up to them, out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Where's Sarah? ,

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (puts finger to lips) SHHH. (whispers) She's in there with that Van Pelt guy. ALAN (whispers) * Doing what? PETER (whispers) Creating a diversion. Alan, perturbed, looks inside the store. as  —~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saran, frustrated, takes another route.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Go on and kiss me you big handsome brute. Sarah kisses Van Pelt. He gruffly takes her in his arms and kisses her back. And suddenly.... ALAN (0.s.) Sarah? SARAH, startled in mid kiss, opens her eyes. ALAN stands in the threshold, blinking. He can't believe it. Sarah is heartstoppingly beautiful. Van Pelt throws Sarah aside and goes for his gun. Alan rushes Van Pelt, knocking the gun from his hands. It CLATTERS to the floor. Alan and Van Pelt go at it. A brutal fistfight rages through the hardware store. The fight knocks over the KEROSENE CAN, spilling a large puddle on the floor. Van Pelt knocks Alan down, dazing him. Alan lies in the pool of kerosene, shaking his head. Van Pelt grabs the EMERGENCY FLARE and prepares to strike it and send Alan up in flames. Alan grabs a shovel (the floor is covered with tools from the fight) and whacks Van Pelt's legs, flooring him. The Emergency flare scuttles across the floor. Both men get to their feet. Alan punchs Van Pelt so hard that Van Pelt falls backward, landing on a ROLLING DISPLAY CART of garden seeds. THE CART rolls down the aisle, ramming Van Pelt's head into the kerosene shelves. van Feit gets to his feet with a KEROSENE CAN stuck to - Kerosene begins soaking the linen shell of the helmet. Van Pelt grabs up the emergency flare. ALAN AND SARAH are standing in the pool of kerosene. A tense pause. Alan throws up his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Van Pelt. There is a can of kerosene on your head. Put the flare down. Van Pelt just smiles. Begins to ignite the flare.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Do not light that! Van Pelt strixes the flare, It ignites. Van Pelt cocks his wrist to throw the flare; the flame leaps from it to the kerosene can stuck to his head! A PLUME OF FLAME bursts skyward from Van Pelt's pith helmet! He struggles with the chin strap. He can't get the bloody thing off! .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Van Pelt bolts from the store, a human roman candle. He charges headlong down the street, his pith helmet ablaze, pulling at the chin-strap buckle.

dialogues.speaker: ARRRGGGGHHHH
dialogues.text: Sarah and Alan dash out with the gameboard. Judy stands on the sidewalk. Peter is gone.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Come on!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Wait! (looks around) Where's Peter?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Up there. Alan and Sarah follow Judy's gaze to A TREE in front of the store. PETER sits in the limbs. PETER'S FACE is covered with hair; his head is simian- shaped. The game's curse haS worked. Peter has become a monkey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god..... And Peter, almost in tears, says in a very small voice:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Is this gonna go away? Alan, Sarah and Judy look at each other.  87.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: When we finish the game. c'mon. Peter hops down and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora, wet and bedraggled, walks down the street, nervously looking around. It's just beginning to get dark; in the surrounding woods JUNGLE SOUNDS create an unsettling atmosphere. She rounds a corner and sees -- IN THE ROAD AHEAD - BENTLEY. is locked to the door of his cruiser, rattling the handcuffs, cursing. NORA runs up to hin.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: My keys! Over there! Nora runs across the road to Bentley's keys. As she picks them up and begins to return to Bentley -- SEVERAL VINE TENDRILS come out of the woods and grab for her ankle, just missing. NORA runs up to Bentley and hands him the keys; he unlocks himself.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Thank-you. What's your name, maam?

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Nora Shepherd.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Where do you live, Mrs. Shepherd? ACROSS THE STREET ~ THE VINE TENDRILS snake across the street and now we see that they are the mere ends of AN ENORMOUS VINE STALK as thick as a telephone pole. ’ NORA Blair Street. The old Parrish place? Bentley's ears prick up instantly.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: You got kids? A boy and girl about eight and twelve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cr 88.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Yes. (alarmed) Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you on the way. Get in! Bentley gets in the cruiser; Nora runs around to the passenger side and SCREAMS -- INSIDE BENTLEY'S CRUISER - BENTLEY looks up as -- THE HUGE VINE STALK lunges through the window. BENTLEY dives out of the cruiser and rolls away as -- The vine stalk drags the cruiser sideways across the road. It disappears into the foliage as if it's been eaten. NORA AND BENTLEY look at each other, gulping. They walk off down the road without a word and -~ cut To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan, Sarah, Peter and Judy approach the Parrish Home. ALAN is looking SARAH over; specifically, her dress and stockings; she looks unbelievably desirable. ALAN and SARAH lock eyes. Alan, up to this point, has not looked upon Sarah in a romantic way.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (self-consciously) what?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Nice dress. Should we keep playing or do you want te go back to your boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Would you like to rephrase that?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You kissed him. I can't believe you kissed Van Pelt. I mean Sarah, c'mon, are you that desperate?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (outraged) What? You think I liked it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: am 39.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Sure looked that way to me.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Alan, she did it to get the game. ot (beat) God, it sounds like you're jealous.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Jealous? Of her and Van Pelt? (outraged) You think I'm jealous of Sarah and Van Pelt? :

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I would be. (to Sarah) She's beau-ti-ful.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (blushing) Thank you, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Jealous? Who're you kidding.... (he walks off) Give me a break.... Alan stalks off, ahead of the group. Peter runs to catch up with Alan. Sarah and Judy are twenty paces behind.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hey Alan? I'm sorry I cheated. Alan doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dad was like you ~ adventurous - and he knew all sorts of people. (stops himself) Maybe I shouldn't say this... (beat) You remind me of my dad. Alan. stops. He turns to Peter.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Peter, I'm not your dad. I don't know anything about being a dad. I didn't even know anything about being a son. Alan walks ahead, leaving Peter standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The foursome walks up the walkway, Alan opens the front door, followed by the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter and freeze, staring in awe.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Oh my God. REVERSE ANGLE - THE PARRISH HOME INTERIOR - the walls are thick with vine. The CRYSTAL CHANDELIER in the foyer casts light through leaves, creating a dappled effect on the floor. JUNGLE SOUNDS echo; animal calls, screeching and purring and growling. The echos create a vast sense of space in the roon. EVERYONE stares at the room, very unnerved. cUuT TO: THE GAMEBOARD opening on the coffee table and WIDEN TO -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four players around the coffee table. The game is about to resume. We PAN from face to face. SARAH. JUDY. ALAN. PETER. (he's a monkey) Peter picks up the dice.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Who's turn?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Mine. Sarah grabs the dice from Peter. She sees Alan staring at her legs. She pulls her dress down. Judy and Peter smile. Sarah tosses the dice. Her piece moves. She reads her rhyme.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Every month at the quarter moon; There is a monsoon in your lagoon.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Monsoon? Good thing we're inside.

Miraculously (because we're indoors), there is FLASH OF LIGHTNING and THUNDER overhead. The most torrential rain storm ever filmed falls in the living room. A monsoon. A biblical deluge. Visibility is five feet. The room is instantly flooded with a foot of water. The water is rising impossibly fast. The storm is so violent the characters must SHOUT. (They will continue to do so until the rain stops.)

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS
dialogues.text: Alan, Peter, Judy and Sarah run through three feet of water now inte the foyer, heading for the staircase, where they encounter -- TORRENTS OF WATER cascading down the staircase, from the mezzanine above. It is terrifying, like a flash flood. They try to climb the stairs but the water flow is too powerful. They get pushed back. The water's now neck deep. Judy and Peter are treading water.. Alan looks around, thinking fast. He sees THE HUGE CRYSTAL CHANDELIER in the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: COME ON
dialogues.text: But SARAH'S looking down the hallway, apoplectic.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Alan and the others turn to see -- TWO 25 FOOT CROCODILES, as big and as terrifying as great white sharks, paddling down the hallway toward the. living room.

dialogues.speaker: SWIM
dialogues.text: The house now resembles a JUNGLE LAGOON. Overhead, THUNDER RUMBLES and LIGHTNING CRACKS. PIECES OF FURNITURE float past. THE FOURSOME swims to the chandelier with -- THE CROCODILES hot on their tails. The foursome reaches the DINING ROOM TABLE floating like  ed a
a raft beneath the chandelier. ALAN gets there first, pulling himself up. He helps the others up. The crocodiles emerge from the water next to the table. Judy sees them and recoils:

dialogues.speaker: AHHHHH
dialogues.text: The CROCKS lunge, SNAPPING at the foursome's feet, then falling back in the water. The water continues to rise! Alan makes a "stirrup" with his hands.

dialogues.speaker: CLIMB
dialogues.text: Alan hoists Judy, then Peter into the "limbs" of the \ chandelier. Judy has the gameboard. The water continues to rise. The CROCODILES circle, licking their chops. The chandelier is swinging and spinning with the shifting weight of Judy and Peter. Suddenly A CROCODILE dives up and lands, WHUMP, on the other end of the sideboard, raising Sarah's and Alan's end like a teeter-totter. The table SMASHES into the chandelier, rocking it. PETER loses his grip and falls in the water!

dialogues.speaker: AHHH
dialogues.text: SARAH slides down the table (it is inclined about 30 degrees) toward the crocodile. Her feet slam against the crocodile's snout, a foot on one jaw, a foot on the other. ALAN reaches down and grabs Peter by the tail, pulling him up as PETER'S HEAD is pulled SNAP!!! out of A CROCODILE'S JAWS. SARAH looks around frantically. The Crocodile opens and shuts his mouth, scissoring Sarah's legs open and shut. Sarah SCREAMS! Suddenly ALAN explodes into frame, grabbing the crocodile bodily, rolling with it into the turgid water. Alan and the crocodile wrestle, thrashing about in the water in an intense fight to the death....  ABOVE - SARAH AND THE KIDS look down on Alan's predicament in horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora and Bentley approach the house. They hear SCREAMING within. As they draw closer, they see a STREAM OF WATER coming from under the door. Bentley draws his gun.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Let me handle this, ma'am. Bentley grips the doorknob and turns it. A WALL OF WATER containing HALF THE FURNITURE comes flushing out the door. BENTLEY AND NORA are blown off the stoop and flushed into the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like somebody let the cork out of a bathtub. Alan and ‘the crocodile are swimming against the tidal pull of the flushing water, like they're swimming in Place. The crocodile flushes out the door. Alan grabs the side of the doorway and hangs on as the water and furniture and everything else in the bloody Place flushes out into the street. He gets up quickly and hops up onto the table. He helps down Judy and Peter. Next comes Sarah. She slides down into Alan's arms. They stand there on the table. Their faces are close.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You...you would have died for me. They stare into each others eyes. The moment is charged. Then Alan breaks away and hops. down.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Come on! They dash for the stairs. Judy still has the gameboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The foursome sprints up the stairs. Alan leads them down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going!?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: The music room! Alan opens the music room door and they pile inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the other rooms, grand and imposing. Instruments on the walls. A bookcase of sheet music. A coffee table and chairs, a loveseat, and a big sofa. An ENORMOUS GRAND PIANO in the corner. The foursome sits in chairs around the coffee table. They're all business now. No one speaks. Alan rolls. His piece slides forward; he reads:

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: "Nature plays a little trick, the sand you're on is very quick." Alan's chair instantly sinks.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Get away! Quicksand! Sarah grabs the dice, Peter grabs the game board. Everyone dives from their seats and tumbles away as - THE FLOOR BENEATH ALAN becomes a churning POOL OF ‘QUICKSAND. It enlarges. Then more and more until the ir With Alan in its center! Alan frantically clings to a chair, then a coffee table. He's engulfed in sand, and going down fast. Sarah, Judy and Peter watch in horror. They are frozen, paralyzed with fear. s

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What should we do? What should we do?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Sarah, think of something....

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (panicking) I don't know... ALAN is now chest deep....

dialogues.speaker: ALAN '
dialogues.text: Somebody think of something.... Everybody looks around frantically. Sarah sees a MUSIC STAND in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I know! She runs to the music stand, grabs it, and races back to Alan. She extends the legs to Alan. Peter and Sarah grab the music rack side and pull. The music stand is telescopic and it pulls apart. ALAN sinks deeper! Now PETER gets an idea. He runs to the wall and pulls down A TROMBONE. He runs back to Alan. The coffee table has sunk beneath him. Alan's neck deep now.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Here Alan, grab onto this! PETER extends the slide of the trombone to ALAN, who clutches it. Sarah and Peter grab the MOUTHPIECE end.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Ready? Pull!!! They heave ho and the trombone pulls apart. Sarah and Peter collapse against the wall and -- -- ALAN sinks even deeper!

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You honeheads! Stop giving ne things that come apart! SARAH sees a CURTAIN CORD running up the wall. She . pulls it down and throws one end to Alan. Sarah and Peter grab hold of the other end and PULL. It's no use. Alan. continues to sink. JUDY, meanwhile, is kneeling next to the board. She makes a quick decision. She picks up the dice and throws them. Her piece moves. Her rhyme appears. She begins mouthing the rhyme. .

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: "Is there no thing one thing that learn you.... (stops; closes her eyes, concentrating; :. she tries again) "There is...one thing...that...you will learn.... The quicksand's about to take Alan. Sarah lies down, reaching up to the elbows in the sand, trying to pull Alan out.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: ..Sometimes....go you." No. “Sometimes you go...back a turn! ALAN (in the sand) and SARAH and PETER now hear Judy. They look at her as she shouts triumphantly --

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: "There is one thing that you will learn; sometimes you go back a turn!" JUDY'S PIECE MOVES BACKWARD and -- THE POOL OF QUICKSAND is instantly transformed back to floorboards and carpet, restoring everything the way it was, except for -- -- ALAN and SARAH. Alan's head, and Sarah's forearms remain trapped in the floerboards and rug in the same position as when the quicksand was there. 10: ike a. Ww i - his head is tilted back so only the front half of his face (eyes, ears, nose, etc.) is showing above the rug, as well as his two outstretched forearms and hands. He can move his hands. Sarah's hands are trapped, her butt sticking up in the air. Their faces are inches apart. Everyone kneels around Alan's head. Alan says, with forced calm, to Judy:

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I thought you couldn't read.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I never had to. (smiles) Until now.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Sarah and I would like to get out of the floor now. I believe it is Peter's turn.  2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter fetches the gameboard and dice. Sarah and Alan are almost kissing.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You never answered my question.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Did you think of me?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Every day for twenty-six years. They exchange a tense smile. Peter rolls. His piece moves. Peter reads:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: “They march and eat and march and eat; if I were you I'd watch my feet." . We HEAR a BZZZZ and suddenly --

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CORNERS OF THE ROOM
dialogues.text: disappear in the wake of a teeming, swarming MASS OF ARMY ANTS. Fifty thousand ants, in a ring, converge on Alan and Sarah in the middle of the room, eating everything in their wake! The ants reach the sofa and tear into it.... BZZZZ2Z....and the sofa begins to disappear. The ants begin eating their way across the roon! Judy's and Peter's eyes bug out. Sarah is quivering. ALAN'S HEAD watches the ants approach.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: You gotta be kidding me.... (snaps out of it; frantically now) They like wood! Give 'em furniture! Peter and Judy drag furniture across the rug in front of the ant's path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora, stunned and bedraggled, approaches the house again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B222222 - the coffee table begins to slowly sink to the floor as the ants tear into the legs!  98. Alan stares at the shrinking coffee table in terror.
= My dad had an axe in the woodshed out back. Get it and chop me out of here!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'll get it! PETER races for the staircase while -- JUDY drags an OTTOMAN LOVESEAT in front of the ant's path. BZZZ2ZZ2Z......

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: comes racing down the stairs. He turns the corner and runs down the hallway toward the back door. CAMERA PANS from PETER exiting the shot to -- NORA entering, looking around in horror at the carnage. She walks to the living room. Looks up at -- ALAN'S LEGS and SARAH'S HANDS stuck through the ceiling, dangling in the middle of the living room. She hears SCREAMING above. She goes upstairs. Cb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter runs up to the woodshed. The door is PADLOCKED. He looks in the window. He looks around, panicking. He sees a RUSTY AXE leaning against the side of the shed. He grabs it and begins CHOPPING at the padlock, so he can get into the shed, so he can get the...... He suddenly stops. Looks at the axe. He looks directly INTO CAMERA. He runs inside with the axe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora comes down the hall. She still hears SCREAMING and COMMOTION. She goes to the end of the hall. She-°- chooses her bedroom. She opens the door to see --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE LION, snoozing on NORA'S BED, wakes up and sees -- NORA OUTSIDE THE ROOM. c Ne THE LION smiles. The he ROOOAAARRS and bares its teeth. Nora SLAMS the master bedroom door just in time as the  oo om

lion springs at her. Nora turns, coming face-to-face with -- PETER, who comes up the stairs with the axe. And he looks like a monkey! Peter approaches her. Nora, terrified, backs up from this axe-wielding monkey!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Himom. It's me, Peter. Can't talk right now. See ya. Peter races inside the music room as -- NORA SCREAMS and backs away, whirling, coming face-to- face with a POISONOUS VIOLET VINE. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER enters with the axe. JuDY‘S rolling the GRAND PIANO into the path of the oncoming ants, which instantly rip into it, BZZ2Z22z2. The piano begins to slowly lower.... JUDY grabs the axe from Peter. She begins to furiously CHOP the rug and floorboards around Sarah's hands. One hand is freed. Then the other. Sarah pulls her hands out and grabs the axe from Judy. Sarah begins to CHOP the rug and floorboards around ALAN'S HEAD. Alan closes his eyes, flinching.

dialogues.speaker: , ALAN
dialogues.text: Uhh...be careful with that Sarah.... THE ARMY ANTS are five feet away, moving through the grand piano, BZZ22Z, like a chainsaw.... SARAH is chopping furiously. She chops through the rug and floorboards on one side of Alan's head. She chops through the rug and floorboards on the other side. Wood is flying everywhere. Suddenly Alan's hands wriggle free from the splintered floorboards! And now he can move his neck! THE ANTS are finished with the grand piano - the only things uneaten are the pedals and the piano wire! And on the ants come, swarming for Alan's head! ALAN wriggles free and pulls himself up as the ants swarm around the hole in which he was trapped.
Alan, Sarah and the kids run from the music room into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come out, running right into NORA SHEPHERD, who lies unconscious on the floor. HER NECK is stuck with POISON BARBS. Her face is flushed with poison. The POISONOUS VIOLET hovers over her menacingly.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Who is that?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: My mother! Alan sees his BONE-HANDLED KNIFE still stuck in the floor (where he through it to escape the lion). He grabs and throws. SPROING!! it impales the violet against the wall. The violet droops and dies. Alan picks up Nora and runs for the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: The attic! Come on! cuT To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter. Alan lays Nora Shepherd on the floor. Peter sets down the gameboard. Peter and Judy kneel over their mother. Judy panics.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Alan, she's dying!

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Don't worry! We can end the game! Look! INSERT - THE GAMEBOARD - the four TOKENS are grouped near "JUMANJI." Two are closer than the others.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Sarah and Judy are close but I'm closest. Sarah needs a....one two three four... (counts spaces) ».-mine or higher. Judy needs a...seven or better. (beat) All I need is a five.  : —™
ALAN (cont'd) (grabs dice; hands them to Sarah) Roll. Sarah rolts. They tumble to a stop. Her piece moves; her rhyme appears. Peter reads:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: "Now you have a lot at stake; It might get worse, here comes a quake." Nothing happens at first. No sound, no movement. Slowly the walls begin to RATTLE. Then the walls SHAKE. From the very depths of the earth, we HEAR the deepest, most unsettling, bonecrunching RUMBLE we've ever heard. The floor begins to roll and shake. Judy and Peter try to stand but the earthquake throws them to the floor. Now it happens all at once -- THE ATTIC FLOORBOARDS begin to separate as --

dialogues.speaker: EXT, PARRISH HOME
dialogues.text: THE PARRISH HOME lit erally splits in two sections along th . We can see a cross section of the house, td at the jungle phenomenon on each floor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan grabs the dice. He grabs for the gameboard but -- THE GAMEBOARD falls between the sections of house and lands, precariously, between two severed floorboards.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What are we going to do now?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Alan, you can end the game on your next roll. That's her only chance! But they don't have the damn gameboard! Alan pockets the dice. He stands on the lip of the cratered attic floor. Below is evi the earth. Alan looks down. The first ec is fifty feet down, a dizzying drop. Alan runs to the SPIRAL STAIRCASE. He slides on the banister pole, spiraling around and around until he

comes to a point where the banister is severed. Alan leaps from the banister to -- A HANGING VINE. He SWINGS down into the crevice between the two sections of house, SNAPPING off jagging pieces of floorboard as he swings. He swings past the gameboard, SNATCHING it, and jumps from the vine, landing --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- in the center of the living room. Alan sets the boardgame on the floor and pulls the dice from his pocket. He calls upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Hang on, I'm almost there! I can end the game with my next roll! He's about to toss the dice when suddenly.... . VAN PELT (0.s.) DON'T MOVE. Alan whirls around. Across the living room comes -- VAN PELT, his pith helmet burned and scorched. Only the ribs of the helmet remain. He trains his rifle on Alan. Van Pelt cannot see from this vantage point the GAMEBOARD on the floor behind the couch. — He crosses the room. Gun leveled at Alan's head.

dialogues.speaker: VAN PELT -
dialogues.text: What is in your hand?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: VAN PELT
dialogues.text: Drop it. Alan's clenched fist is directly over the gameboard. . SARAH (0.5s.) You'd better do what he says. SARAH clambers down from the broken staircase. ALAN opens his fist. THE DICE fall from his hand. One die falls onto THE GAMEBOARD, landing "3." THE OTHER die hits the edge of the gameboard, bounces,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ce) om
scuttles across the floor and rolls into the earthquake crevice, landing on its edge on a small ledge below. ALAN and SARAH stare, wide-eyed at the die in the crevice! And Van Pelt cocks his gun!

dialogues.speaker: VAN PELT
dialogues.text: Now I have you. THE DIE ON THE LEDGE begins to wobble. VAN PELT'S FINGER moves to the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: VAN PELT
dialogues.text: You will not escape me now. (cocks gun) Thanks for the hunt. VAN PELT'S FINGER begins to squeeze the trigger as -- -- THE DIE IN THE CREVICE finally rolls over, landing "2."  ALAN'S TOKEN, in CLOSE-UP (it is huge), advances onto the "JUMANJI" SQUARE. Alan yells --

dialogues.speaker: ' ALAN
dialogues.text: Jumanji! -- as VAN PELT pulls the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Nooo! Sarah steps in front of Alan to take the bullet. THE BULLET from Van Pelt's gun exits the barrel, flies through the air and -- DEMATERIALIZES in mid-air, one foot fron Sarah's head. Sarah SCREAMS. Alan holds her tight. Time seems to stop. There is a RUSHING OF WIND, whipping round and round the walls of the living room. ALAN and SARAH, IN CLOSE-UP, exchange looks as each knows the game is ending. VAN PELT whirls around, terrified. His gun flies from his hand, vaporizing. ' i ‘ ' 7 in 7 . Suddenly the wall | explodes and everything from the world of Jumanji is within this swirling circle of wind --  '.

-- the vines; the monkeys; the big mosquito; the rhinos and elephants; the: crocodiles; the pelican; and finally Van Pelt -- And one by one, the Jumanji phenomena are compressed and sucked SHHHUUUMMMPPP!! into the center of the board, VAN PELT going last, his head stuck like a cork in a bottle. SHUMMMP!! he's sucked in and he WAAAIIILLLS back into the world of Jumanji. Then all is still. CAMERA is still tight on the gameboard, but PULLING BACK, it's no longer on the living room floor, but ona coffee table. CAMERA TILTS UP to the faces of -- ALAN PARRISH and SARAH WHITTLE, ages 12 and 13 again, clinging to each other in the living room, exactly as they were in 1969. Their mouths open. They biink. THE PENDULUM of the GRANDFATHER CLOCK is swinging again and we HEAR the last two GONGS. We HEAR the front door opening. Alan and Sarah, startled, turn to see -- SAM PARRISH enters.

dialogues.speaker: . SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: Forgot my notes. He continues into the dining roon. Sarah and Alan turn back to each cther. Sarah picks up Judy's token.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (sadly) Judy. Alan picks up Peter's token.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (same) Peter. Sam Parrish renters the foyer, his 3X5 cards in hand.

dialogues.speaker: SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Dad? Alan gets up and walks into the foyer. Father and son stare at each.  oN 7

dialogues.speaker: SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: (coldly) What. Alan runs to his father and hugs him. And Sam Parrish, startled, almost overwhelmed by this, slowly returns the hug.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about what I said. I'll go to camp if you want me to. The break from the hug, regarding each other. Alan's tone has been uncharacteristically sincere. Sam is still surprised and somewhat skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: What's the catch?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: No catch. I just want to be a kid. Alan smiles. And Sam Parrish, startled by this exchange, smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I'll...see you later. He walks to the door. Dad? Sam Parrish stops. Turns.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Today in the factory? It wasn't Carl Bentley's fault. It was mine. Sam Parrish stares at Alan, non-plussed.

dialogues.speaker: SAM PARRISH
dialogues.text: I'm glad you told me. Sam Parrish shakes his head (he doesn't really understand what just happened) opens the door and exits. Alan stands in silence in the foyer. He looks at his 12 year-old body in the mirror. Sarah appears next to him, also looking in the mirror. She runs her hands over her chest. Alan rubs his whiskerless jaw.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: It's like we never played.  b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan and Sarah, riding double on Alan's bike, pedal up to the bridge. Sarah holds a PAPER GROCERY BAG. They stop in the middle. Sarah holds open the bag; Alan reaches inside. He pulls out the JUMANJI Box; it's clasped shut; two big ROCKS have been tied to it with twine. Alan steps to the railing and heaves the box over. The JUMANJI BOX plunges into the turbulent river, landing with a SPLASH!! Alan and Sarah watch the game submerge.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I'm starting to forget what it's like to be a grown-up.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Me too. That's okay, as long as we don't forget each other.

dialogues.speaker: , SARAH
dialogues.text: Or Peter and Judy. They look into each other's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: There's something I've been wanting to do.... And Sarah Whittle kisses Alan Parrish on the lips. They smile at each other. They walk to Alan's bike, holding hands. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again Brantford is picturesque, prosperous and active: it's an updated, 1995 version of the town we saw when 12 year-old Alan Parrish was riding his bike in

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: Brantford, Connecticut - 1995

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old mill house is gone. In its place is a corporate complex: sleek structures,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: om) 1907. cutting edge architecture. A new, more modern sign announces: "PARRISH SHOES, FIVE GENERATIONS OF QUALITY." CAMERA CLOSES IN on a window on the top floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very posh and urbane. Vast windows look out on Brantford River and the rolling hills beyond. A MAN is behind his desk, looking out the window while speaking on the phone. We do not see him.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Charlie, I know he's just a basketball player, but he's going to sell a lot of shoes. Here, I'll put you on with my vice-president. The swivels around. It is ALAN PARRISH, 37 now. His hair is neatly trimmed. His tie's tucked in, his shirtsleeves rolled. He hands the phone to -- CARL BENTLEY, 45, in suit and tie, the vice-president of Parrish shoes. Bentley smiles and takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: See ya tomorrow, Carl.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Have a good night, Alan. Alan rises, puts on his suit jacket, and heads out. cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house as we first saw it in 1969. Grand and charming. Lights twinkle within. A car comes down the street and pulls into the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan, @ressed casually, is on the phone. In the background we see DISHES OF PREPARED FOOD.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: And the new wing turned out a lot better than we thought.... The front door bell RINGS. The kitchen door opens. SARAH pushes open the door. She enters the kitchen. She is several months pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Honey, they're here.  108. SARAH (cont'd) (as she exits) This is so exciting.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: -Listen, dad, my new marketing director's in town and they've come for dinner. (beat) Great... Give mom my love. Alan hangs up and smiles at Sarah. They exit into the hallway. IN THE FOYER - together they go to the front door. They pause a second, then Alan opens the door. A MAN stands in the threshold, mid 30's, smartly dressed, with intelligent eyes. He smiles broadly and extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Good evening Alan!

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: (shaking his hand) Jim! Welcome aboard! Sarah extends her hand.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: * Hi Jim, Sarah Parrish.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: My pleasure. (looking over his shoulder) Here's some people you haven't met. Honey? NORA SHEPHERD appears next to her husband. Then JUDY and PETER, just as we left then. Alan and Sarah exchange a private smile.

dialogues.speaker: . SARAH
dialogues.text: You must be Judy and Peter.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY AND PETER
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Come in, come in! Alan ushers in Judy and Peter and their parents. They move into the living room, Nora and her children gazing around at the grand space.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Oh my goodness.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Wowww! Alan goes to the sideboard, comes back with TWO SHOEBOXES. He hands one to Judy, one to Peter.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN
dialogues.text: Call this a "welcome to Parrish Shoes present.” Go ahead, open them. Judy and Peter excitedly take the shoe boxes from Alan. SARAH turns to NORA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids are so excited about moving here. The school's system's great f hear, especially for Judy. (smiles, watching her daughter open the present; whispers to Sarah} She's got a little dyslexia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loox, mom! Judy and Peter hold up state-of-the-art SNEAKERS, very stylish.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (reading the back of the sneakers) Air...Ju...man... ji'ts! ALAN and SARAH exchange another furtive look: (do they remember?) But Peter just shrugs and says:

dialogues.speaker: PETER ,
dialogues.text: That's a weird name for a sneaker. Alan and Sarah exchange a private smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA looks through the foyer windows as Alan and Sarah and the Shepherds move inside, their voices continuing: ALAN (v.0.) you're dad's going to find a way to market it, Peter. Did you know he's an advertising genius?

PETER (v.0.) He's a better hiker! Nora and Jim LAUGH. . - NORA SHEPHERD (v.o.) Peter's still angry we had to miss our vacation. We go every year. Jim loves to vock climb. CAMERA moves back to the STREET, taking in the whole house. . ALAN (v.0.) Not any more - he's too valuable to me now! Everyone LAUGHS. CAMERA CRANES up and pulls back, taking in all of Brantford. It is twilight and all is quiet, except for the sounds of CRICKETS, which grow louder and louder and louder.... FADE OUT. ROLL CREDITS. FADE IN, aS CREDITS continue to roll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A forlorn GIRL, 12, walks down the beach. BOY (v.0.) Adele! Adele! Ici, ici! She turns. The she runs off toward -- A BOY, his trousers rolled up, standing in the surf. The girl runs up. The boy holds something in his hands. He wipes SEAWEED off it. It's a BOX we've seen before.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Quel est'il, Francois?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Regard. Jew. Mon. Gee! They walk off excitedly together. The foamy surf rolls in, splashing on the beach. The ominous jungle theme music comes up. CREDITS END. FADE TO BLACK.
